poll_list.title: Ratification Poll for Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards (MIP81) - October 10, 2022

content.content: MIP81: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards  Preamble MIP#: 81 Title: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards Author(s): @CB_Institutional  Contributors: Tags:  Status: Accepted Date Proposed: 2022-09-06 Date Ratified: 2022-10-24 Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mipxx-coinbase-usdc-institutional-rewards/17703 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmbMaQ9A   Sentence Summary MIP81 will onboard an account representing MakerDAO to Coinbase Prime and transfer 33% / ~1.6B of the PSM’s USDC into custody to earn USDC rewards with Coinbase.  Paragraph Summary MIP81 onboards a portion of the PSM’s USDC to Coinbase Prime in order to participate in Coinbase’s USDC Institutional Rewards program. This MIP outlines the terms for reward calculation and the process for payment to MakerDAO through 2022.  Motivation This proposal responds to the ratified Declaration of Intent MIP13c3-SP12: Invest in Short-term Bonds, wherein MakerDAO governance requested that collateral assets be deployed in a manner that incorporates evaluative criteria of: safety, cost structure, and flexibility. Coinbase is uniquely situated to offer a USDC Rewards Program to MakerDAO that meets this evaluative criteria. Specifically, Coinbase is an established, reputable, and regulated company.  Coinbase has been a longstanding partner of Maker’s, most recently collaborating with the Growth Core Unit (GRO-001) and the Strategic Finance Core Unit (SF-001) to understand what opportunities would be of interest to the broader DAO community. Maker’s balance sheet is largely exposed to USDC — in exchange for zero holding reward. Maker believes it is beneficial to safely be rewarded for holding collateral in USDC. This MIP outlines a clear path to providing up to 1.5% APY on USDC in the form of USDC Rewards and optimizing liquidity at zero cost to, and industry-leading security for, Maker.   Component Summary MIP81c1: USDC Onboarding Process & Rewards Program Terms This component outlines the process for onboarding to Coinbase via an appropriate legal structure and governance framework and the terms of Coinbase’s rewards program. MIP81c2: Legal Verification & Oversight This component contains the requirements of legal oversight and disclosure to the Maker community.  Specification  MIP81c1: USDC Onboarding Process & Rewards Program Terms USDC Onboarding Process  If MIP81 is approved, a subsequent Signal Request must be posted by the Strategic Finance Core Unit, CES Core Unit, or Growth Core Unit, and passed to onboard a legal entity approved by Maker Governance. A Strategic Finance Core Unit facilitator will seek approval for a specific legal entity (the “arranger”) in the weekly cycle to serve as permissioned actors on the account. The legal entity structure, governance framework, and necessary contractual arrangements must be appropriate to act as a large-scale custodian to Maker. This includes, but is not limited to:  No ability by third parties to access the funds or change the terms of the legal structure. Maker Governance has complete ability to trigger a liquidation with a successful executive vote encoding an instruction to the authorized account users of the legal entity. It should not be possible for a single third party to block the ability of Maker Governance to make decisions or modify the structure. There must be no apparent weak links or edge cases that allow funds to get misappropriated or stuck.   The arranger is responsible for ensuring all standard KYC and AML due diligence requirements have been met in accordance with Coinbase’s obligation as an entity offering Prime Services. Consistent with the standard Coinbase Prime offering, the arranger will be authorized to deposit and withdraw assets between the PSM and Coinbase so long as they’re successfully onboarded and authenticated. Their permissions will be limited to the actions described in this proposal: USD <> USDC transactions to and from the PSM. In the future, Coinbase and Maker will automate transactions between the PSM and Prime account via smart contract or API. Maker Governance’s approval will facilitate onboarding to Coinbase Prime.  Coinbase’s USDC Institutional Rewards Program  Maker will pay zero custody fees on USDC held with Coinbase Prime. Maker Governance will be able to freely mint, burn, withdraw, and settle almost instantaneously in USDC (<6 mins), consistent with Coinbase Prime’s standard offering. Rewards from the USDC account with Coinbase will be calculated based on the weighted average of assets on the platform each month and paid on the 5th business day of the following month. Each month, Coinbase will calculate the weighted average holding of the account. Coinbase will pay rewards based on our USDC Institutional Rewards POC program rates:  100bps APY on first 100mm 10bps more APY on each 100mm thereafter Rewards rate will be paid based on the highest tier the client falls into Rewards are not to exceed 150bps APY   USDC Institutional Rewards POC will be in effect until the end of 2022, and the final payment will be made on the subsequent month. Assuming the pilot program continues beyond 2022, Maker will remain enrolled for 2023 and beyond. Terms could become variable, but Coinbase Institutional will provide an update to the Maker Forum at least 30 days prior to any changes. Rewards will be paid into the client’s account in USDC.   MIP81c2: Legal Verification & Oversight  At least one community member, with legal credentials, must, through a public forum post, verify that the proposed entity is appropriate to onboard to Coinbase Prime. A CES facilitator must, again through a public forum post, provide a verification of the technical appropriateness of the MIP81 designated solution. Should the verification not be forthcoming, this MIP will not move forward. A member of the CES Core Unit will verify the address destination and the legal entity’s Prime account prior to transfer of funds. A test transaction will take place to ensure the receiving address is correct prior to any release of funds. If CES is not satisfied with the security of fund transfer, the deal would be halted until these concerns were rectified.

content.content: So, Maker’s Growth Core Unit went out and proactively approached Coinbase in a quest to move PSM collateral, which already poses an existential threat to DAI, into an additional layer of completely centralized corporate custody? Layer upon layer upon layer of existential centralized risk just so that the DAO can justify continued overspending? Even while a large portion of the DAO understands that USDC-PSM is posting an existential threat that needs to be eliminated asap? Do you understand that moving the USDC to Coinbase will add yet another regulatory attack vector that the DAO needs to worry about? Circle won’t even need to blacklist the PSM any more. The government can just force Coinbase to seize the funds and kill DAI instantly. So much easier for the government to understand. Fits so much more neatly into existing framework than creepy “blacklisting”. A vote for this proposal is a vote to place the entire fate of DAI and MKR in the hands of Coinbase, a publicly-traded corporation that does not have aligned interests with the not-so-decentralized MakerDAO.  If that’s what you want… then honestly… why are you even here? Should we just sell the entire DAO to Coinbase instead at this point? I mean… what exactly are we doing here? I absolutely reject the premise of what’s being proposed here and I am also now thinking that we should discuss a proposal to offboard Growth CU. Growth CU’s incentives do not seem to be aligned with decentralization nor with the long-term survival of Maker. Proposals like this are putting CU jobs & salaries ahead of the long-term well-being of Maker and DAI. This was bound to happen as the humans of MakerDAO tipped the balance of power from the smart contracts to themselves. Maker needs to figure out how to get rid of the USDC as quickly as possible, it needs to cut costs dramatically and immediately, and it needs to develop a roadmap to full automation within 2 years.

content.content: Exciting opportunity for MakerDAO! Can Coinbase Prime team explain where the variable 1.50% rate is coming from and provide a risk-reward analysis on the capital deployment strategy? Particularly looking for details on:   Counterparty risks: Which counterparties or platforms does CB Prime plan on utilizing for this yield? How does CB Prime measure counterparty risk?  Concentration risk: What is the diversity of platforms, strategies, and counterparties this capital will be deployed to?  Market risk, - which asset prices and interest rates would this deal have exposure to (direct or indirect)? How much would 1.50% APY move if  Net Leverage: How much gross and net leverage will the strategies used to get this return take on? With the ongoing credit crunch in crypto, borrower rates across the board have gone up which makes this 1.5% rate seem quite low. Will there be any form of real-time monitoring that the DAO understands the collateralization of the strategies?  Liquidity profile: You mentioned DAO can freely transact in USDC and returns are paid on 5th of T+1 month. Can principal be withdrawn monthly? What would the rates look like with that flexibility added?      CB_Institutional:  Coinbase will pay rewards based on our USDC Institutional Rewards POC program rates:  100bps APY on first 100mm 10bps more APY on each 100mm thereafter Rewards rate will be paid based on the highest tier the client falls into Rewards are not to exceed 150bps APY

content.content: BP333:  Well, the USDC in existence is 100% backed by US-dollar equivalent from Circle. I’m wondering if that’s the same risk as Coinbase in case of insolvency.   Not exactly - the USDC is issued by Centre https://www.centre.io/ (founding members Circle/Coinbase), which invests the USDC in short-term money market instruments and holds these investments in custody with various institutions in the US (this is their latest attestation report chrome-extension://efaidnbmnnnibpcajpcglclefindmkaj/https://www.centre.io/hubfs/PDF/USDC%202022_Circle%20Examination%20Report%20July%202022.pdf?hsLang=en). Currently, any income on investment by Centre is not distributed to USDC holders. I suspect that the motivation for this proposed deal is customer retention. Instead of converting our USDC into dollars (thereby reducing the total supply of USDC) - it is locked into custody with no impact on the supply of USDC. Instead, Coinbase is sharing some of the investment income received on Centres’ short-term investments - (that indirectly they will probably receive in some form from profits made by Centre - my speculation). Therefore, the level of risk is a function of the custody arrangements. Generally, as I understand it, Coinbase provides segregated custody and cannot re-hypothecate or use the USDC Maker would custody for any purpose. So they won’t be using the USDC to make any income - it just sits in custody until Maker removes it - so there wouldn’t be any “celsius” type risks. Assuming MKR token holders want to proceed with onboarding this proposal, I am sure that a complete MakerDao legal assessment of the proposed custody arrangements would be completed to determine to what extent other parties could have claims on Maker’s assets - say, in a bankruptcy situation and the necessary information provided by @Growth-Core-Unit, and @strat-fin-core-unit regarding the nature of the custody arrangements.

From the perspective of a smaller investor who really does want MKR to succeed, I encourage the community to take this offer.  With how slow the RWA efforts are going, Coinbase is giving you a lifeline to strengthen the balance sheet and lessen the time pressures you’re faced with while you figure out how to better decentralize your assets.  In one fell swoop you can put all your assets to work without losing that all important liquidity.  Yes, Coinbase is still a centralized entity but it’s also tied deeply to this space and I’d like to believe that this proposal is one that partially comes from a desire to help MKR and strengthen the entire defi ecosystem.  Use this opportunity to get profitable and stay there while you work. To Coinbase, I wonder what happens to the institutional rewards POC (what is this?) rates at the end of 2022.  We’re pretty close to the end of 2022 so it would be wise to figure out how the terms might change in 2023.

content.content: This is a great (and long overdue) initiative. I will of course be supporting it fully and help to vote it through, alongside the other major yield proposals in the works, as they are fully aligned with the Endgame Plan and the strategy of Pigeon Stance - first we need to double down on RWA and focus on generating as much short term income as possible, that we can use to accumulate Staked ETH to give us the option to later switch to a more defensive stance if/when the risk of RWAs become too high. The estimates I’ve seen is that we should expect 70-80 million in yearly revenues with just this first wave of yield generation activities. That doesn’t mean we should keep splurging on the current badly structured version of the Decentralized Workforce, rather we need to reduce the recurring budget as much as possible so we maximize the surplus that can be used to accumulate decentralized collateral with the Protocol Owned Vault. If we can get revenue to 80 million per year, and reduce costs to 25 million per year, that gives us a yearly surplus of 55 million. The current version of the Protocol Owned Vault Emulation MIP specifies a leverage of 1.8x, which means we would be able to use this cashflow to accumulate almost 100 million USD worth of Staked ETH per year. Add to that that there is still more Dai demand available to allocate into higher yielding opportunities, and that with the Endgame Plan we would begin driving Dai demand through MetaDAO yield farming, our changes of accumulating a decently sized protocol owned vault over the next 3 years are looking good.

content.content: This is a summary of the subproposal and its effects upon ratification from GovAlpha’s perspective:  This is a valid proposal, eligible to enter the October Governance Cycle. This MIP takes on MakerDAO’s intent to invest in short-term bonds, as formally expressed through MIP13c3-SP12: Invest in Short-term Bonds. This proposal aims to use 1/3 of the USDC in the PSM to get Institutional Rewards in Coinbase Prime with up to 1.5% APY on USDC. Maker will pay no custody fees on USDC held with Coinbase Prime. An arranger selected by SF-001 will act as a permissioned actor on MakerDAO’s Coinbase Prime account. The arranger will be responsible for ensuring all standard KYC and AML due diligence requirements; furthermore, they will be authorized to deposit and withdraw assets between the PSM and Coinbase so long as they’re successfully onboarded and authenticated. USDC Institutional Rewards POC will be in effect until the end of 2022, and the final payment will be made in the subsequent month. Maker Governance has the complete ability to trigger a liquidation with a successful executive vote encoding an instruction to the authorized account users of the legal entity. This proposal has been assigned High-Impact based on the methodology listed here. This MIP is eligible to enter the October Governance Cycle.

content.content: The USDC that Coinbase uses to pay USDC Institutional Rewards comes from Coinbase’s inventory of USDC. Coinbase funds the inventory from its own purchases of USDC from Circle, from purchases of USDC from users of the Coinbase platform, and from payments that Coinbase receives pursuant to its revenue sharing agreement with Circle, the issuer of USDC. Each USDC is backed by one dollar or asset with equivalent fair value, which is held in accounts with US regulated financial institutions. USDC Reserves are managed by Circle, the issuer of USDC.  Circle audits the USDC Reserves annually in addition to monthly attestation reports which are published on Circle’s website showing the size and composition of the USDC Reserves. For more information, see USD Coin (USDC) | Crypto that’s held to a higher standard | Circle. The Rewards Rate is set at Coinbase’s discretion and is not directly tied to yield generated by assets held by Circle in USDC reserves.

content.content: Thanks! Coinbase Custody International is a private company limited by shares and incorporated under the laws of Ireland, is not registered or licensed in any jurisdiction. Coinbase Custody International offers custodial services to clients in jurisdictions where registrations and/or licenses are not required to offer such services. Coinbase, which wholly owns Coinbase Custody International, is registered separately with the U.S. federal Money Services Business and the Financial Crime Enforcement Network (FinCEN) and licensed with the New York State Department of Financial Services (NYDFS). Coinbase treats all Prime client assets as custodial. Assets held in our vaulted solutions are held in segregated accounts, specifically named on behalf of the client owner. Client assets cannot be deemed as Coinbase assets and are not subject to any claims from Coinbase creditors. No Coinbase entity will sell, transfer, loan, rehypothecate, or otherwise alienate client assets credited to the client’s Trading Account or Coinbase Custody wallet unless explicitly instructed to do so. Within Prime Trading Balance, Coinbase keeps the majority of assets in cold storage to maximize security and manages the percentage of assets kept in hot wallets to facilitate rapid withdrawals. The percentage of assets maintained in cold versus hot storage is determined by ongoing risk analysis and market dynamics. Factors that impact rebalancing include insurance coverage, client activity, and market activity. We seek to ensure client liquidity needs are balanced with optimizing assets in the most secure storage possible for those needs. All assets held within the Prime Vault Custody are kept in a 100% offline cold storage environment. Coinbase Custody International, Ltd. offers the same industry leading crypto asset storage that has made Coinbase Custody the world’s leading custodian. The international entity is designed to meet the needs of institutional investors in Europe.

content.content: ChrisBlec:  Do you try to make friends with the government and commit to moving to a new version of DAI that allows for blacklisting & censoring txs?   This can’t be done without shutting down the current protocol and migrating it to another one, the way SAI → DAI.  This means the ERC20 that is DAI, would free float to the collateral basket and need to be migrated.  The migration worked from SAI to DAI because DeFi was still young, but we’re beyond the point where this could work. This is what immutability means in this space.  It’s a statement of “we can’t” vs. “we won’t”.  It’s a commitment more durable than the US constitution, and is the strength of smart contracts: that one can build on top of them as solid and immovable foundations. The question should be: do MKR holders want to build decentralized, censorship resistant, permissionless, and immutable foundational building blocks for DeFi, or do they want to do what captured tradfi web2 has been doing for a decade?  One of these things requires blockchains, the other requires SQL databases.

content.content: ACREinvest:  Everyone should worry about bankruptcy risk all the time, today, tomorrow and forever. Hope is not a strategy for success in managing our business here. We will have the Lehman anniversary in 8 days and as some of you know I was a lawyer for the commodities & energy trading business in the belly of that beast. So, I must dis-abuse anyone who thinks a large public firm going under is not something to really worry too much about.   Of course it’s possible.  In fact, that’s why I referenced the fact that they lost a billion dollars in a quarter.  It’s extremely possible.  What I’m saying is that public companies are more regulated and should theoretically provide more transparency.  This is a good thing and helps decisions down the road.  But yes, there are many examples of public companies that have misled the public so your point is not without merit.  I guess it all comes down to a question of risk and trust which really is the root of many, many discussions on these forums. If MKR wants to get rid of all the expensive RWA efforts and just go back to simple roots of cryptocollateral without a PSM, I think the protocol could survive quite well.  Sure you’ll have stability issues that might undermine some DAI demand but limiting all your collateral to decentralized crypto solves all your trust issues. However, with the PSMs, the RWA exposure, the larger workforce we’ve created a protocol that’s much larger in scope, ambition, and unfortunately exposure to centralized counterparties.  So I’ve accepted the RWA plan and to me that means finding a way to transition while you’re figuring it all out.  With RWA the surplus buffer matters greatly in how much you can scale to meet DAI demand.  That’s why I focus on profitability.  Because in order to reduce reliance on USDC, you need to lend and in order to lend safely, you need more money in the SB, and in order to get a bigger SB, you have to take a little bit of risk.  How much risk is the question we’ll never stop arguing but the reward here is quite appealing and let’s not forget that it scales up and down with PSM size.  Ultimately, we want yield from better and more diversified products…this just helps us get there. In terms of what happens in the Coinbase bankruptcy scenario, actually I agree with you.  I wouldn’t want to do anything reckless.  I fully support due diligence and looking for guarantees that even in a bankruptcy scenario, MKR would be able to receive its funds back.  Again, I think Coinbase being a public company helps you in those analyses.

content.content: Overall this is a well thought out proposal and I really appreciate the thoughtful discussion!  While there may not currently be consensus on whether Pigeon Stance and USDC are the best for DAI, assuming some of the bankruptcy and regulatory risks are no different than the status quo, this aligns with the Pigeon Stance proposal and is a no brainer in that regard. My personal view is there should be a governance vote on whether RWA should continue and/or the MIPS related to the EndGame timeline prior to a vote on MIP81. Across the forum posts there is a real split among delegates and stakeholders as to whether USDC collateral should be retained and this is leaking in to all the discussions. To move forward in a productive way, I think it would be best to vote on that specific issue and put it to bed to ensure better alignment on MIP81 and any future MIPS.  Further Questions on MIP81     CodeKnight:  “Whats in it for Coinbase?”   This was my major question as well. I think @CB_Institutional answered most of the other questions well here, here and here. The only other questions I have remaining are: 1. What happens to those funds in the event of a Coinbase, Coinbase Custody International and/or Circle bankruptcy? For Circle (as described here)  Money transmission laws provide that Circle maintains legal title to the USDC reserves, but does not have an equitable interest, unlike a bank or exchange or an unregulated institution. This distinction matters. USDC reserves are assets that belong to USDC holders, not Circle, and are wholly held in segregated accounts designated “for the benefit of USDC holders.” Circle is not allowed to use the USDC reserves for any other purpose. Unlike a bank or an exchange or an unregulated institution, we cannot lend them out, we cannot borrow against them, and we cannot use them to pay our bills. In the most unlikely and extreme stress case of a Circle bankruptcy, segregated USDC reserves should remain redeemable at face value, shielded from Circle creditors, and separated from a bankruptcy estate per the protections afforded under state money transmission laws (e.g., Section 651 of the New York Banking Law) and applicable federal bankruptcy laws (ask your bankruptcy counsel about the meaning of 11 U.S.C. §§ 541(b)(1) and 541(d)). To be clear - the USDC reserves are separate from the rest of Circle’s business and operations and are protected by laws and regulations.  Does this custody relationship mean that Coinbase or Coinbase Custody International would be the beneficiary? Would Maker (via a legal entity)? Would it be DAI holders or MKR holders?     Traster_Tray:  in a bankruptcy scenario, as a debt holder, MKR would be first in line to receive its funds back.   Not a lawyer, but I’m not 100% convinced this is the case. As we’re seeing with Voyager and Celsius, the more intermediaries there are, the more complex the rightful beneficiary chain gets if there is a bankruptcy. Especially depending on the terms and the jurisdiction of the bankruptcy proceeding. I’m unsure if this Maker → CBI → CB → Circle layering jeopardizes that or actually further insulates Maker’s risk. More details needed here and I would recommend an independent legal opinion alongside a response from @CB_Institutional. 2. DAI Sanctions or Security Classification Risk (as better described by @0xbocaJ below )     0xbocaJ:  how would you treat our deposits if (I) another user of DAI was added to the OFAC sanctions list, (II) the PSM address or another address closely associated with this deal were added to the list, or (III) a major MKR holder or governance related address were added to the list?   The same questions could be posed if the SEC decides to rule DAI a security. What happens then? 3. Does this change the regulatory capture of DAI or MKR? As discussed here, DAI or MKR holders having a claim to an interest bearing asset (yield on USDC) may constitute an investment contract and therefore increase the likelihood that MKR and/or DAI are classified as a security. My personal view (not a lawyer) is this increases the likelihood of DAI being classified as a security or derivative and then question #2 above applies. 4. What insurance coverage is there for $1.6B? What would it cover? My understanding is that no one in the crypto industry has an insurance tower to cover this much value in crypto, in either hot or cold. Unless self insurance is occurring… While FDIC only covers up to $250k (if structured correctly) from my understanding Circle is trying to split fiat deposits across different banks to maximize this coverage and reduce counterparty risk at the bank level. While that’s a pittance compared to $1.6B I’m curious if parking $1.6B in USDC with CBI adds additional protection or negates it. Further clarification would be great!   Cases for rejecting MIP81 Apart from the risks associated with the outstanding questions above, I see 2 higher level questions that impact the acceptance of this MIP and haven’t really been adequately addressed.   Is there alignment on the End Game Pigeon Stance strategy around using USDC and other RWA to generate more protocol owned value? If not, then this should obviously be rejected.   Can Maker do this better and reduce counter-party/regulatory risk by putting treasury to work directly? Even if it can, would that align with the long term decentralized goal? If the answer to both of these questions is “yes” then it should be rejected in favour of Maker being more vertically integrated.   The second set of questions is dependent on the outcome of the first, hence why I think it’s best to get consensus on Pigeon Stance first.  On More Vertical Integration of RWA @Arby articulates the same thing I’ve been hinting at in other forum posts      Arby:  may I ask why the need for a middleman? Maker as a DAO has sufficient presence within the space to incorporate itself in a much more favourable jurisdiction than that offered by Coinbase? If MakerDAO was forced to choose a jurisdiction in which to incorporate and asset selection for 1.6B of exposure, I would assume that a better decision could be made. This is a separate topic to whether Maker wants to become a bank or not.   If the plan during Pigeon Stance is to do RWA and maximally grow revenues over a three year period, then why not set up a regulatory compliant entity for 3 years to interface directly with a bank, reduce  counter-party risk and increase revenue? This would likely also reduce your regulatory risk because you’ll have to be vetted and approved by the bank’s compliance teams and have a proper legal and custody structure to undertake the yield earning opportunities without having to worry about the risk of a rapid shut down from being classified as a security. This has the potential to make the Pigeon Stance period longer and more flexible. Since it seems a legal formation will be required to execute this MIP and the expectation is that funds don’t need to be super liquid anyway, it seems like this option should be considered if Pigeon Stance MIP is approved.  Once an entity is set up, Maker could redeem the $1.6B USDC via Circle and take the USD to multiple reputable banking partners outside the US to hedge risk. You’d be able get better interest rates via more direct T-Bill, Money Market fund or Eurodollar lending exposure. I can introduce to reputable banks that would gladly do this for a portion of the $1.6B. The downside to this is it may take longer and be more work than MIP81 to execute and unwind if Eagle Stance were activated.  In Summary I think it is great to at least see this proposal exist! Even if it doesn’t materialize, it has very quickly surfaced a thoughtful discussion on the pros/cons which can be used to guide future MIPS and decisions. I appreciate @rune commenting on how he thinks it aligns with the End Game because initially it seemed to be slightly divergent than what has been discussed in other MIPS and governance posts.  I’m still of the belief that DAI has the potential to split the difference between how USDC and USDT operate, and be a better alternative to both (more decentralized and more transparent/automated). There is more than one way to skin a cat and this could be an important step along this journey but a few more details are needed and I think we need to vote on other End Game MIPS first. Looking forward to seeing more details

content.content: I’m trying to understand the economic rationale for this proposal. Clearly the core team needs money to operate this protocol that is foundational for crypto; I just don’t understand how this proposal is good for Maker. Finance is essentially about return and risk. A quick look at alternative returns shows that Maker could get 2.31% in the overnight repo market, or $36.96 million annually. Compared to the $22.5 million offered by Coinbase, this leaves $14.46 million in lost revenues to Maker. But, actually, risk needs to be taken into account, so this return is too low since Coinbase isn’t as secure as lending to the US government. Coinbase has a junk rating (S&P BB with a negative outlook). So, it is better to compare similar expected returns for BB credits. In this case, an investor would demand a 4.92% return (not the 2.31% demanded if lending to the US government). This would mean that a BB borrower would pay $78.75 million per year. By going with Coinbase and not what is available in the market, Maker would be losing $56.25 million per year. Actually, it is worse than that. Bond holders are in a secure position, at the top of the liquidity preference in the event of insolvency. With Coinbase, Maker’s deposit is unsecured. Meaning that all other lenders to Coinbase would have a preferential distribution in bankruptcy. So, unsecured lenders would ask more than 4.92% for taking on this additional risk. But, it is actually worse than that. Bond documents set out a use of funds. So, for example, you have to use funds to build a plant. With Coinbase, there is no use of funds clause. Actually, depositors don’t have use of funds protection rights; Coinbase can do whatever they want with deposited funds. It isn’t clear to me how they generate the returns or what the use of funds are, but it seems like a traditional finance prime brokerage type operation, where Maker’s funds would be loaned out to counter-parties of Coinbase. So, there is a further credit risk, but this cannot be evaluated. You don’t know and you just need to trust them (even if Coinbase is an impressive organization). I see that the proposal is a response to MIP13c3-SP12. This is about investing in short-term bonds. It seems misleading to suggest that this proposal satisfies a resolution to invest in bonds, as bonds have a very different risk profile than an unsecured deposit in Coinbase. In reality, bonds would give Maker a much safer risk exposure and much higher returns. I’m not a Maker insider and I find the Maker terminology extremely hard to understand. I just don’t know why anyone would even consider a proposal like this. From a finance perspective, it doesn’t make any sense. Maker can do much better. But, I must be missing something. Maybe someone can help. I’m actually thinking of making an alternative proposal about how Maker can earn revenue while keeping to a decentralized philosophy (and align risk and return). I see DAI as so fundamental to a healthy crypto industry. But, if I have got my analysis wrong, maybe someone can help me before I waste my time. I’m also not an insider, like I said, and if proposals can only come from insiders who can figure out the terminology I won’t bother. I’ve seen some comments about holding USDC in treasury being the same as accepting Coinbase’s proposal. Legally, this is completely untrue. An asset that you own and have possession of is completely different than depositing (unsecured lending) that asset. Essentially, you go from owning the asset to legally transferring title (ownership) of that asset to someone else. If you hold it you are the owner. If you lend it, you are an unsecured creditor and Coinbase owns it. I also don’t understand the principle of DeFi going to TradFi to get returns. Isn’t the whole principle of DeFi that it offers better returns than TradFi, so TradFi will come to DeFi? If DeFi has to go to TradFi for yield, what is the point of DeFi? If this proposal were to be accepted, wouldn’t DAI just become a digitally wrapped version of the US dollar? A much worse version, since it comes with higher risk and lower returns. Maybe someone can tell me where I’m wrong, so I don’t waste my time with an alternative proposal. Here is a quick analysis I did. content.content: We get 6 min withdrawals, how much more liquid can it get

@RobertSharrat, your analysis takes the perspective that it is a secured loan. Under this assumption, your conclusions are probably valid - i.e. not enough return given the risk profile of Coinbase. However, as I understand it, this will not be structured as a secured loan arrangement; there will be no loan agreements or security -  and Coinbase is not being provided loan proceeds to do as they choose. Instead, Maker would fund a Real World trust that would solely take direction from Maker token holders and will be approved to deal with Coinbase concerning the management and opening of a Coinbase Prime Account and the movement of funds to the trading/custody account from the PSM. Given this, and until the proposal has been explored in further detail and more information on structure determined - I think it is premature to conclude anything about the adequacy of the proposed rewards. As I understand it, the Coinbase Prime Account - generally provides two sub-accounts 1) a trading account (I assume some hot wallet) and 2) a Custody account provided by Coinbase Custody International - which is supposedly a segregated custody account - which Maker would have sole control over - i.e. Coinbase cannot touch or move these funds only Maker (or, possibly a bankruptcy court, in the case of a Coinbase bankruptcy based on the intended legal nature of the proposed arrangements). Regarding risk, each month’s rewards will be paid by Coinbase Inc. based on the balances in the Coinbase Prime accounts.  So assuming an aggregate balance of ($1.6 bn).  The risk for this stream of reward income would be approx. US2mm per month. If this is not paid or it appears that it will not be paid, Maker would be free to move the entire balance out of Coinbase - which would take approximately 6 minutes from when an instruction is given. The critical risk issue is concerning any underlying USDC balance we have in Coinbase Custody - if we cannot get an opinion that in a bankruptcy scenario, Maker Funds would not be segregated from other Coinbase unsecured creditors - then the risk of being able to withdraw under this scenario is a Coinbase Inc. risk - in which case some of the arguments you are making about the yield not being sufficient may be valid. However, if we can’t get adequate legal comfort on the nature of the custodial arrangement  - maybe there are technical ways some of Maker’s concerns could be addressed that meet the objectives of both parties, which could be further explored. For example, what if a smart contract can be developed to hold funds in the Coinbase Custody account that automatically returned funds to Maker’s PSM -  in the event of non-payment of rewards by a specific date? Or under this smart contract, Coinbase is only permissioned to move funds to the PSM and Maker approved addresses - so they retain control (but limited to Makers approved addresses). If such an arrangement were possible and automated, it would be a different risk profile - where the proposed rewards might be an attractive return for the risk profile. All the preceding are likely worth exploring by the entity that becomes the arranger/maker’s real-world trust administrator and Maker specialists. But it would probably require an underlying understanding of the technical nature of Coinbase Custody arrangements and any APIs in place to manage those funds. So, ignoring the debate over whether Maker should be interacting with the real world, I think it would be remiss at this time to make any conclusions about whether the risk-return profile is acceptable - until we have a better understanding from risk and technical specialists about what exactly is the risk profile of this proposed arrangement.     RobertSharratt:  I see that the proposal is a response to MIP13c3-SP12. This is about investing in short-term bonds. It seems misleading to suggest that this proposal satisfies a resolution to invest in bonds, as bonds have a very different risk profile than an unsecured deposit in Coinbase. In reality, bonds would give Maker a much safer risk exposure and much higher returns.   Concerning the above, you are correct that the above MIP was about investing in bonds - the context and motivation being to redeploy the approx. US$4bn USDC sitting in the PSM and earning no income for Maker. In that respect, this proposal is somewhat related to the motivation behind the referenced MIP. It is perhaps something that could be implemented in the short term as it will take some time to off-board Maker’s stablecoin balance and redeploy to a bond trading operation - let alone ensure we have the required treasury management personnel to manage a bond portfolio/several portfolios.

content.content: I think the part you’re missing is that Maker does not have access to an overnight repo market the way banks do.  If concepts like treasuries or the repo market come on-chain some day, then a lot of the friction would go away.  But right now, in order to get access to yields and be able to lend, you have to either lend DAI collateralized by crypto on-chain or go through third parties and buy bond etfs or handle the lending process.  All of the third party stuff takes a lot of work with cuts taken by every middleman in the process.  Coinbase is offering something as close to the overnight repo as we can get and removing a lot of that work for Maker (in fact, seemingly even more liquid which is what Maker needs).  Yes, they’re going to take a substantial cut.  But I would say it’s worth it to allow Maker’s workforce to focus on other types of collateral. Fleshing out the bankruptcy risks is important but at least Coinbase seems well capitalized for now.  They lost 1.1 billion last quarter but 446 million of that was a one time impairment loss from the crash in prices.  Since then there has been talk of cost cutting as well so one would project future losses to be smaller.  From their past earnings call - … we did set a guardrail that if we went into a winter that we would operate to a $500 million loss. Based on that statement and their 6.2 billion in cash, they should be able to operate fine for at least a few years before having to raise more capital or cut costs further.

content.content: Its clear Coinbase is just passing a portion of the yield generated by its USDC FIAT collateral (interest at banks or USD treasuries) by having USDC remain onchain. Excess deposits at bank are not lent, and the bank is earning interest in the interbank market and passing some of that interest to its depositors.

content.content: @TRUEMAKER I think your analysis is right on: it is a defensive move by Coinbase not to lose money from Maker. If there were a way to go from DAI in crypto directly into a bank account in the real world, there would be no need to pass by Coinbase. That is what scares them: that the Maker community finds a way to access normal yields in the traditional space and therefore not to be beholden to Coinbase to exchange from crypto to fiat. I guess a bigger question is: why do these exchanges have to exist? In my analysis, the opportunity cost of putting $1.6 billion with Coinbase is a loss to the Maker token holders of $56.25 million per year. Also, on a technical point: bank deposits are also legally unsecured loans to the bank. They are often protected by capped depositor insurance, but they are a transfer of title to the bank. You can see it in banks’ balance sheets: deposits are an asset (owned by them). The IOU is a bank account, which is a liability of the bank.

content.content: @Traster_Tray I think that you identify one of the biggest issues in crypto: the hard separation wall between on-chain and the traditional world. For sure the core team should not be doing financial engineering; they should be focused on building Maker. And, I agree that they need money right away to operate this fundamental protocol. I think that this issue raises an existential issue for crypto: if you cannot easily move from the on-chain world to the traditional world, what is the point of crypto? If you cannot spend your DAI to buy coffee (or invest in bonds), how is it going to change the world? Same the other way: if you want to buy DAI with USD why is it so hard? I recently bought just over $500,00 worth of DAI. I have an institutional account at Genesis Global Trading and my tech team has integrated their APIs. Confirming the trade took seconds. Great. But, then we have to wire them the money through the traditional banking system. I bought on the Friday before Labor Day and the wire didn’t get to their US bank from us here in Switzerland until Tuesday, because of the holiday. I had set up an experimental DAI - digital dollar pool on Balancer on Arbitrum, so people could buy DAI directly from their bank account with us using fiat currency. And it ran out of DAI, as so many people on-ramped (selling fiat currency to buy DAI, so we had no DAI left). I’m not sure I’m going to continue with it, as the process is such a hassle. Imagine if to access the internet you had to go through some centralized choke point every time. That is basically what Coinbase, Binance, etc are and it is the biggest impediment to crypto adoption, I think. If I can’t spend DAI on my debit cards or use DAI to buy a house or invest … or if I cannot buy DAI directly with my USD, what’s the point? It’s as useless for normies as it is for Maker’s treasury people.

content.content: This is all great discussion and analysis but we’re kind of bike-shedding at this point.  Apologies for repeating myself but I think there are two questions that need to be resolved before this moves forward: 1. Should Maker continue to have RWA exposure? More specifically, USDC exposure? @rune makes the case for “yes” in Pigeon Stance and previous MIPs have already been approved that say “yes”, but there is clearly a lot of contention on these two points. @rune would you or someone from Governance CU be willing to put this up for a vote in order to streamline future discussions?    Endgame Approval MIP Set - next steps   I have been working on the MIPs and will post most of them in a few hours. Any that remain will be posted tomorrow to ensure they all can enter RFC and be edited to completion in time for the October voting cycle.   Have yet to see these MIPs (apologies if missed them). Not trying to be pushy but IMHO putting this issue to bed will greatly increase execution efficiency and seems like the logical next step while we wait for @CB_Institutional to respond.  2. If yes, does MIP81 have a better risk reward profile than the current way PSM USDC is held? As many have already articulated, addressing concerns around loss of funds in the event of bankruptcy/loss in the custody/issuer chain and/or the implications in the event a sanctions or securities ruling occurs against DAI/MKR is critical to making a fair assessment here. If the proposed arrangement with Coinbase doesn’t materially differ from the status quo in these scenarios and there is consensus on the proposed Pigeon Stance plan, then I agree with @rune here - lack of action is objectively worse than acting.     rune:  FWIW I think it is quite likely that we can find better deals elsewhere over time - but there is no doubt to me that this is the only deal available to us that can be scaled to a billion+ within a relatively short amount of time. MIP65 is also very scalable and would likely get closer to market rate, but it seems to me like it will not be nearly as convenient as this when it comes to redeploying the money elsewhere. Right now we should be more focused on how much of the idle USDC we can deploy, rather than how high we can squeeze the rates. Once all of it is properly deployed into something that pays any kind of safe yield and can be easily withdrawn again, then it starts to make sense to increase the yield further by optimizing in smaller chunks with things that are a bit more complicated.   Earning ~150bps with Coinbase vs. 0 with Circle is clearly better than the status quo if all risks are considered equal. If this is the case, MIP81 should have unanimous support from the camp that supports RWA and USDC because there is only upside compared to the existing risk profile. While there may be other RWA opportunities that provide a better yield (which there are few MIPs), this would very clearly move faster than any other option. My suggestion is that anyone with concrete alternatives put forward their own MIP as opposed to further polluting this thread. I will submit a draft once I’ve seen a vote that determines how much current support there is for continued RWA and/or USDC support. If there isn’t enough support, all this is just a waste of everyone’s time.  Speaking from experience dealing with many TradFi firms, regulators, and banks with regards to crypto-assets, a crypto-native institution like Coinbase will move way faster than one that is crypto curious because they already understand the technology, the risks and have the operational expertise. I’m looking forward to seeing details on the aforementioned issues and contract terms so we can put to a vote ASAP. Time is not on our side with currently proposed MIP…     CB_Institutional:  USDC Institutional Rewards POC will be in effect until the end of 2022, and the final payment will be made on the subsequent month.   Lots of people are excited about the idea of earning X millions per year, but there seems to be an assumption that this is a multi-year deal. Unless there are private discussions happening that contradict the original proposal, MIP81 is presently only until the end of 2022, which is effectively only 3 months of yield (maybe) if this slots into the October voting cycle. Realistically, we’re squabbling over just $6MM in USDC rewards, which is going to start decreasing as soon as October 1, 2022 is hit unless the USDC is in Coinbase custody. $6MM in protocol revenue is not nothing but is not the $23MM+ that previous comments are touting. The longer this discussion goes on, without an extension into 2023, the risk/reward profile changes rapidly. As each day passes we’ll end up closer to the same spot we’re currently in - $0 in revenue with the same USDC risk profile. To make this worth anyone’s time we should have responses/opinions on the custody & default risk ASAP or the proposal gets extended beyond 2022.     CB_Institutional:  Institutional Rewards in 2023 and beyond may be variable and updated for all participating clients on a periodic basis. To your point, this means it is possible that the APR will fluctuate in the future, and potentially rewards will become higher, or lower than 1.5%. Of course, all changes will be communicated with reasonable advance notice.   @CB_Institutional eluded to this being a possibility, so it would also be good if they can comment on the likelihood of extension and the terms/conditions of that. Patiently awaiting End Game MIPs and more details…

content.content: In catching up on this thread, I was greeted with a notice that said: “This is the first time @RobertSharratt has posted — let’s welcome them to our community!” So first - let me share a heart felt WELCOME and assure you that we strive to be a community where “insiders” do not have special powers. Tag @ACREinvest anytime.     RobertSharratt:  I’m also not an insider, like I said, and if proposals can only come from insiders who can figure out the terminology I won’t bother.   This is the time of year I get especially feisty. Today is the Monday it happened 14 years ago. In two days, it will be the exact anniversary date of September 15, 2008. Surely a lot of us are here because of what kicked off on that day. This Delegate Platform is very friendly to compliance and RWA and finding a practical way forward to navigate the current waters. That said, we are not here to gloss over short-cuts and pure money grabs by interested parties who push this community to ignore important issues and tell us to just YOLO. See e.g.:     rune:  but there is no doubt to me that this is the only deal available to us that can be scaled to a billion+ within a relatively short amount of time. MIP65 is also very scalable and would likely get closer to market rate,   There’s another date I want to remind everyone about: October 31, 2011 (interesting anniversary there too. The point of the tough inquiry here is that even if the terms and structure all check out, RISK is about what happens when there is a breach of the agreements. The bankruptcy analysis we need to consider is not only what happens if our transaction is sustained as expected through the life of the business engagement until the point of bankruptcy filing…     Eumenes:  The worst outcome is that Coinbase enters bankruptcy and Makers funds are tied up in bankruptcy court for an extended period before eventually Maker takes a significant loss on this large position that not only wipes out the Surplus Buffer but creates real losses on DAI holders. Such a scenario could likely end Maker.   But also, we must anticipate our situation if things are entirely different on the ground in the last hours, as was the case of MF Global when customer funds that were supposed to be segregated and protected from creditors were not actually.   FRONTLINE    What Happened to MF Global's Customer's Money? | FRONTLINE Seven months since MF Global filed for bankruptcy, here is what is known about the brokerage firm's customers and what happened to $1.6 billion worth of their missing money.  Est. reading time: 4 minutes       We have every reason, right and opportunity to raise the bar on our due diligence standards and expectations for this protocol and DAO. LFG

content.content: Here’s a simpler arrangement that accomplishes something similar: Coinbase decides to start paying Maker an incentive for holding USDC. Example in plain language:  If Maker holds >$10 MM USDC, then Coinbase will pay monthly an incentive equal to ~1.5% variable APR directly to the USDC address(es) based on average daily balances.  Coinbase still “wins” by keeping USDC in circulation and making >1.5% on the investments undertaken by Centre. Maker avoids additional complexity and potential incremental counterparty risks. Maker also wouldn’t be incumbered by an agreement not to sell the funds or with a delay. Such an arrangement is likely worse for Coinbase (they can’t advertise adoption of their new fancy tool), but it avoids the need to park assets with a custodian.

content.content: With all due respect, I am asking for Coinbase’s response. No one else’s.

Hi Everyone, Thank you for your thoughtful comments and dialogue. It’s exciting to see so many community members committed to finding the right solution for MakerDAO, and we want to help you achieve your goals by offering a secure, low-risk means of generating value on a portion of the assets otherwise sitting idle in the PSM. We appreciate that not everyone in the community shares the same vision; as such, we’ll aim to empower your discourse with facts. There seems to be some misconceptions about the structure of this deal and its risk profile, so we’d like to clarify those points, then address some broader themes.   Deal structure: Some commentators have speculated that Coinbase would control Maker’s assets or erroneously assumed there is some type of “loan” arrangement. This is not a loan and there is no unsecured lending proposed here. We do not control your assets. This is a proposal to transfer ~1.6B USDC to Coinbase Prime which will earn a 1.5% reward. The assets would remain under the sole discretion of Maker. Coinbase will NOT sell, transfer, loan, rehypothecate, or otherwise alienate client assets credited to the client’s Trading Account or Coinbase Custody wallet unless explicitly instructed to do so. Assets held in our vaulted solutions are held in segregated accounts, specifically named on behalf of the client owner.   Risk profile: There seems to be a misconception that holding USDC in custody at Coinbase adds risk. There’s two components to consider here: a) the inherent risk of USDC, and b) any incremental risk associated with holding USDC at Coinbase.     a) Just like Maker and Circle, Coinbase complies with the applicable law, which includes sanctions implemented by OFAC. This is why Coinbase is restricted from interacting with wallets that are designated by OFAC on its Specially Designated Nationals (“SDN”) List and must take certain action if it comes in possession of assets belonging to such wallets. In general, this will only become an issue if the PSM wallet address interacting with Coinbase becomes designated by OFAC or is somehow associated with a sanctioned actor.   We also want to highlight that Coinbase shares the same interests and values as many in the Maker community regarding economic freedom and technology as a form of free speech - and views the TC sanctions as a threat to DeFi and web3. Specifically, Coinbase is funding a lawsuit brought by six people challenging the U.S. Treasury Department’s sanctions of the Tornado Cash smart contracts. See more here and here about how we are standing with the broader crypto community.   b) A main purpose of Custody is to provide additional safety and security for assets. From a risk standpoint, Coinbase is one of the largest and most trusted crypto custodians. Assets stored in the Coinbase Vault storage solution are secured by a comprehensive system that goes beyond consumer grade hardware wallets and is comprised of physical security, consensus computation, and strict process controls. Custody vault wallets combine cold storage and multiparty computation technologies. Our systems are designed for multi-user operations, ensuring that no individual or small group can act maliciously or be coerced into executing unauthorized transactions and instructions. We offer battle tested security measures which include but are not limited to 2FA YubiKey hardware, video call approval for cold storage withdrawals, activity logs, multi-user consensus approval for sensitive actions, and more.   Coinbase offers some of the broadest and deepest insurance coverage in the crypto industry under a program it has run continuously since 2013. Coinbase offers clients coverage through Commercial Crime ($320M) and Cyber Crime ($3M) insurance policies. The Commercial Crime insurance program covers both cold and hot storage assets held by Coinbase Global, Inc. (“Coinbase Global”) and all its subsidiaries. Fwiw, since our inception in 2013, we’ve never been hacked - while various smart contracts have been.   As for the broader themes, I’ll address these in an FAQ format: 1. Q) What happens to Maker’s assets in the event of a Coinbase bankruptcy? A) You are smart to be concerned about your assets. So are we. The best protection for this, is knowing that the possibility of a Coinbase bankruptcy is highly unlikely. We have a strong balance sheet, audited financials, and are a public reporting company that provides this information publicly here. Our Chief Legal Officer also provided a blog post on this matter, available here. But, we understand: trust - but verify. We place great importance on safeguarding crypto assets we custody and protecting them from the claims of our general creditors. Our client agreements are explicit that Coinbase does not have a property interest in the digital assets we hold for customers. We believe that digital assets held by Coinbase would not be considered Coinbase’s property and would not be subject to the claims of our creditors. Specifically, the contractual terms between the parties provide that digital assets held in custody with Coinbase Custody International Limited (CCI) are held in a segregated custody account, segregated from the assets held by CCI as principal and the assets of other customers of CCI, and will not be treated as general assets of CCI. The parties also agree that the client digital assets constitute custodial assets and client property and are held by CCI in trust for the client. On this basis, we believe a court will conclude that there is a trust relationship between CCI and the client and, therefore, assets held on trust would not form part of the estate of CCI upon the insolvency of CCI. Further, with regard to assets held in custody at Coinbase Inc. under the contractual terms between the parties, they agree that digital assets held by Coinbase will be treated as “financial assets” under Article 8 of the Uniform Commercial Code (“UCC”). UCC Article 8 provides that financial assets held by Coinbase are not property of Coinbase and not subject to the claims of its general creditors. In light of UCC Article 8, we believe that a court would not treat custodied crypto assets as part of our general estate; however, due to the novelty of crypto assets, courts have not yet considered this type of treatment for custodied crypto assets. 2. Q) How secure are our assets / is our USDC going to be at Coinbase? A) Assets will be held at Coinbase Prime with vaulted assets held at Coinbase Custody International and trading balance assets held at Coinbase, Inc. All Client assets held at Coinbase Prime are treated as custodial assets. This means Coinbase has a duty to safekeep and protect these assets on behalf of its clients. Coinbase Custody International, a private company limited by shares and incorporated under the laws of Ireland, is not registered or licensed in any jurisdiction. Coinbase Custody International offers custodial services to clients in jurisdictions where registrations and/or licenses are not required to offer such services. Coinbase, Inc. is a registered money services business with FinCEN under the Bank Secrecy Act, a licensed money transmitter in numerous U.S. states and territories, a licensee under New York State Department of Financial Services’ Virtual Currency Business Activity Regime, commonly referred to as a BitLicense. Assets held in our vaulted solutions are held in segregated accounts, specifically named on behalf of the client owner. Client assets cannot be deemed as Coinbase assets and are not subject to any claims from Coinbase creditors. No Coinbase entity will sell, transfer, loan, rehypothecate, or otherwise alienate client assets credited to the client’s Trading Account or Coinbase Custody wallet unless explicitly instructed to do so. Within Prime Trading Balance, Coinbase keeps the majority of assets in cold storage to maximize security and manages the percentage of assets kept in hot wallets to facilitate rapid withdrawals. The percentage of assets maintained in cold versus hot storage is determined by ongoing risk analysis and market dynamics. Factors that impact rebalancing include insurance coverage, client activity, and market activity. We seek to ensure client liquidity needs are balanced with optimizing assets in the most secure storage possible for those needs. All assets held within the Prime Vault Custody are kept in a 100% offline cold storage environment. Coinbase Custody International offers the same industry leading crypto asset storage that has made Coinbase Custody the world’s leading custodian. The international entity is designed to meet the needs of institutional investors in Europe. 3. Q) Where do the “rewards” come from? A) The USDC that Coinbase uses to pay USDC Rewards comes from Coinbase’s inventory of USDC. Coinbase funds the inventory from its own purchases of USDC from Circle, from purchases of USDC from users of the Coinbase platform, and from payments that Coinbase receives pursuant to its revenue sharing agreement with Circle, the issuer of USDC. 4. Q) What assets back USDC Institutional Rewards? A) The USDC that Coinbase uses to pay USDC Rewards comes from Coinbase’s inventory of USDC. Each USDC is backed by one dollar or asset with equivalent fair value, which is held in accounts with US regulated financial institutions. USDC Reserves are managed by Circle, the issuer of USDC.  Circle audits its financial statements annually in addition to monthly USDC Reserve attestation reports which are published on Circle’s website showing the size and composition of the USDC Reserves. For more information, see USD Coin (USDC) | Crypto that’s held to a higher standard | Circle. 5. Q) What does Coinbase get out of this partnership? A) Coinbase and Maker share a longstanding partnership that we value, as Jenn articulated. What’s more, Coinbase is committed to supporting USDC initiatives given that we powered the launch of USDC by co-founding the Centre Consortium. We firmly believe that USDC is critical to bridging the gap between crypto and fiat, and understand that Maker, as the largest holder of USDC, is in need of a reliable, trusted, collaborative partner who can provide an on- and off-ramp to USDC at no cost. We also consistently seek out innovative ways to support and service DAOs and see this program as a model that potentially can be leveraged going forward. Coinbase Custody International (CCI), like all custody businesses, is also seeking to grow its custodied assets. Through this USDC Institutional Rewards program, CCI is able to partner and support a significant crypto market participant, MakerDAO, in further establishing itself as the industry leading crypto custodian. As some of you have correctly speculated, Coinbase is uniquely suited to streamline USD <> USDC conversion and onboarding. In fact, Coinbase is already facilitating frictionless execution of USDC initiatives at Maker. A great example is MakerDAO’s move to invest $500M in bonds and treasuries - an entity representing MakerDAO is converting USDC <> USD through its Coinbase Prime account in order to execute the transaction. We offer instantaneous settlement (<6 mins), providing high liquidity and high-touch support to our partners. Some have argued that Maker should actively manage its PSM balances. Maker could go and purchase other assets (bonds, treasuries, overnight repo etc.). But, in doing so, Maker would incur heavy administrative and service fees that TradFi institutions extract. Additionally, there is liquidity friction inherent in traditional forms of settlement that is not present with USDC. Coinbase seeks to be a one-stop shop for supporting frictionless transactions across the entire horizon of MakerDAO’s needs. 6. Q) What entity is being onboarded to represent Maker? A) Per guidance from the Maker Growth Core Unit and Maker Strategic Finance Core Unit, it is up to the discretion of Maker Governance to identify a suitable entity to onboard. We have a committed team of Institutional Onboarding specialists ready to assist and streamline the process for Maker. We handle all the heavy lifting so that Maker’s core units can remain focused on strategic matters.

content.content: You’re not wrong. Which is why it probably doesn’t matter if DAI has USDC collateral and funds are with a centralized entity or not. If the DAI smart contract addresses or DAI or Maker itself are banned, DAI usage and circulating supply will significantly contract regardless of the collateral backing. Possibly the contraction is so severe that it kills DAI entirely. Maybe not. No one knows. One could argue that by working with multiple regulated entities that have capital and skin in the game, that risk to DAI decreases because it would have much more systemic risk if it failed or was banned. I made this case here. On the flip side, as I made the case above, this could also increase the likelihood of regulatory capture. The real answer is, no one knows. So instead of incessant debate about hypotheticals outside of our control, we should make decisions over things we can control, with the knowledge we have.  @pcfreak30 by all other posts of yours I’ve read, it’s clear you don’t want USDC backing and are for maximal censorship resistance and decentralization. Lots of others share your same viewpoint including many advocating for this MIP. I also align with you and feel conflicted. But constantly repeating the same thing is not helpful. This is why I made the case in other posts and will repeat here. Maker has 4 options:   Eliminate USDC and RWA ASAP and try to be as algorithmic and maximally decentralized and censorship resistant as possible;   Retain USDC and RWA and embrace regulation. Maybe rethink the notion of decentralization by becoming too big to fail and either forming its own regulated entities or working with existing ones.   Do both in parallel and hedge your bets. Keep current DAI decentralized and inline with option 1. Launch DAIv2 inline with option 2. People can work on the one they are most philosophically aligned with like a decentralized workforce should.   Do nothing.   I think most will agree option 4 is the worst. To me option 3 is the best. @rune is advocating for option 2 first and then option 1 later with his End Game plan. Because there are known unknowns and unknown unknowns with all of them, at some point you just gotta pick and roll with it.  “The enemy of progress is indecision”

content.content: We appreciate the color provided by the Growth CU on today’s G&R (Governance and Risk) weekly call about the pre-work/discussions that proceeded the submission of this proposal, and specifically the nuance that this proposal relates to a new product offering at Coinbase that is being prototyped to some extent with MakerDAO. The latest from Gensler in reaction to the Merge opens up a new front for our consideration! Should have seen this coming, but honestly I had not been thinking lately about how important (from a U.S. financial services legal perspective) is the core distinction between proof-of-work, characterized clearly as “trade or business,” vs proof-of-stake, potentially more like an investment activity. This has sweeping implications. I look forward to hearing @CB_Institutional views on the SEC chair’s statements quoted in this article and their comments on my numbered questions below:    WSJ    Ether’s New ‘Staking’ Model Could Draw SEC Attention SEC chair says system used by ether following software update could trigger securities laws.        What has been Coinbase’s internal discussion to date on how replacing Proof-of-Work with Proof-of-Stake may change the regulatory analysis of whether ether is a commodity or an investment contract?   How does the Chairman’s analysis map to Coinbase’s current regulatory authority to offer the services/product proposed here?   If the characterization of ether changes from commodity to security because of its new proof-of-stake consensus mechanism, would this “taint” all crypto assets operating on the Ethereum network?   How do any of the above observations factor in Coinbase’s internal risk assessment of proceeding with the proposed services/product?   From the article:  Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Gary Gensler said Thursday that cryptocurrencies and intermediaries that allow holders to “stake” their coins might pass a key test used by courts to determine whether an asset is a security. Known as the Howey test, it examines whether an asset is bought by investors hoping to earn a return based on the efforts of others. “From the coin’s perspective…that’s another indicia that under the Howey test, the investing public is anticipating profits based on the efforts of others,” Mr. Gensler told reporters after a congressional hearing. He said he wasn’t referring to any specific cryptocurrency.   If an intermediary such as a crypto exchange offers staking services to its customers, Mr. Gensler said, it “looks very similar—with some changes of labeling—to lending.” The SEC has repeatedly signaled over the past year that firms offering crypto-lending products need to register with the agency and in February BlockFi Lending agreed to pay a $100 million penalty for failing to do so.   What relationship does the current product proposed have with the services Coinbase decided to discontinue a year ago?     TechCrunch – 20 Sep 21    Following SEC lawsuit threat, Coinbase cancels launch of 'Lend' product Coinbase efforts to play hardball with the Securities and Exchange Commission didn’t last too long. The cryptocurrency exchange had garnered the ire of the regulatory commission over its plans to launch a crypto lending product, with the SEC sending... content.content: Hello everyone. Please note that the author has updated the MIP, which now matches the MIP template. GovAlpha still has some concerns about this MIP from the governance side that we would like to see addressed before we present this MIP to MKR voters for approval. Please note that GovAlpha’s concerns are about process and governance procedure rather than concerned with the principle of whether or not Maker should deposit funds with Coinbase. While we have a neutrality mandate, we are also mandated to comment on governance process when we perceive issues. Some of this may seem like semantics, but it is important to have completeness in a MIP as our mandate requires us to carry out the instructions within a MIP, as written. So if a MIP passes asking us to send 1.6 billion DAI to x address without oversight, that is what we will be including in an executive vote. GovAlpha cannot, and should not, be placing barriers in place when executing on MIPs that have been approved by MKR voters. Our primary concerns are as follows:   There is no detail on how Maker Governance can request a return of the funds. This is our most significant issue with the proposal. The MIP states that Maker can ask for the funds to be returned, which on receipt of the instruction, Coinbase can carry out within 6 minutes. However, there is no description of how MKR voters should signal this or how Coinbase should receive that message. This lack of clarity sets us up for a situation where we have a desire for the return of the funds, no access to signal requests which may be made obsolete in the coming month, and governance is therefore unclear on how to proceed further. We recommend adding a dedicated process component that specifies how Maker Governance can request their deposit be returned. Ideally, this would also provide for “routine” and “urgent” requests for return, although this is not strictly necessary. The MIP has been updated to include a provision for a legal assessment from the Maker side. We think this is a good step. However, there is no mention of what happens if this assessment is negative. For example, does the transfer proceed regardless? Or is it blocked from happening?  There is no provision for a technical assessment from the Maker side. We recommend CES should do this. We suggest this includes verifying that the addresses on the Coinbase end are safe and assessing the best method for the return of interest payments and USDC deposits to MakerDAO. For example, how does USDC interest make its way into the Maker Surplus Buffer? Does a returned deposit go straight into the PSM? Does either of these processes need a module to interface with? Suppose this requires further technical work to deploy any modules to facilitate this. In that case, this work should be authorized by this MIP. Similarly, we request details on what happens if CES are not satisfied with the technical aspects of the proposal. Are we to proceed and send funds regardless? Or should the deal be halted until these concerns are rectified?  To clarify, we will allow the MIP to be voted on it’s current state but as per our mandate, GovAlpha is raising these governance issues to the community and voters to make sure they are as informed as possible and strongly recommends the author considers addressing them before formally submitting their proposal.  cc: @CB_Institutional @GovAlpha-Core-Unit @Recognized-Delegates @strat-fin-core-unit @collateral-core-unit @Growth-Core-Unit

content.content: Purely from an economic standpoint, DAI is at a disadvantage (versus other stablecoins) by not earning on its USDC holdings when interest rates have risen. At the extreme, choosing not to earn means boosting revenue generation at Circle which in turn can help boost the competitive position for USDC. So, it makes sense to explore a way to boost returns of USDC holdings. With the US Federal reserve hiking the Fed Funds rate, the CME Fed Funds futures indicates an average rate of 4.25% for 2023. Expect Circle to make slightly higher than this on the USDC issued based on the choice of investments. Circle shares a portion of this earnings with Coinbase (to the extent USDC is custodied at Coinbase) as highlighted by @CB_Institutional in a previous post. This can be validated from Circle’s SEC filings - search for income sharing in PDF. The exact proportion of the rate shared with Coinbase is not clear & can be queried during the Q&A. Also, since Circle’s costs do not increase based on the Fed Funds rate, there is a case to be made for a larger proportion of the higher interest rate to be passed on to Circle & subsequently to Maker via Coinbase Rewards. The competitive changes in the stablecoin industry (see BUSD/Binance shifts) could also favour an increase in payouts.

content.content: From Growths side, I talked about the origin of this particular MIP briefly on last weeks GR call if you want to check it out. It’s quite simple, Coinbase and Growth, and formerly the BD team at the Foundation, have been in fairly regular contact since 2018 if not prior with BD goals starting with getting DAI listed and used across their products ( a very “textbook” Partnership relationship). As mentioned on the call, CB brought this opportunity to us mid summer. It’s a standard for Growth to have many conversations with prospective protocols and current partners about new ideas on collaboration (ie using DAI in something, or using Maker in some way in another dapp/platform). Often times the ideas proposed to us are not a fit from a technical perspective and we help to explain that. Part of Growth is educating people on how Maker works. Not everyone is a Maker expert believe it or not and we don’t ignore people who come to us with ideas regardless if the idea proposed makes sense. I think the Growth CU would have a pretty poor reputation if thats how we operated externally. Further, Growth will sometimes be a conduit to partners for other Core units. For example, adding a vote delegation contract to CB has been requested by MKR holders, DUX (who created the vote delegation contract) and we help to facilitate those conversations, even if CB does not want to integrate it. To be very clear there are ZERO non public arrangements financial or otherwise proposed by Maker CU and Coinbase. That being said, Growth has no influence on if people love or hate their proposal.  CB could’ve easily posted their MIP without sharing the idea with us first but it was naturally helpful for them to ask us. In particular, asking how to create/ post a MIP (also not common knowledge if you don’t live in the forums). I looped in SF to have them understand what the product is and offer any feedback in line with similar proposals in the forum related to investing in short term treasuries and such. Hopefully this is more clear.
