content.content: ChrisBlec:  So the DAO has to trust 4 known people to withdraw $1.6b from Coinbase back to PSM? What if Maker is in the midst of a regulatory crackdown and the government tells those 4 people that if they do this that they’ll go to jail?       ChrisBlec:  Maker has to trust that the 4 individuals are acting legally in all aspects of their financial life, and also has to hope that US regulators don’t ever sanction them.   It was discussed on this video that the entity itself and the individuals involved would need to be squeaky clean. But yes, I agree this is a major risk and clarity on the mechanics is needed before this can realistically moved forward.  Questions/Comments  4 people is not many for $1.6B . Does it make sense to expand to existing CUs and/or Delegates? There needs to be clarity on who the Maker representatives are, corporate structure, and how this will be determined (timeline/mechanism). This should be a condition of the MIP IMHO. Given the Maker representatives will likely need to undergo enhanced screening (more than normal KYC/AML) to reduce risk for the broader community, is everyone comfortable with that? It could mean pretty significant doxing. A couple questions that come to mind that would require answering/proof:  Where are you a legal resident? Have your taxes been paid? Do you have a criminal record? Have you been involved in any pending or completed litigation? How are you securing your signing key?   More clarity is needed on the multi-sig structure. I assume it’s 4 of 4 but this is not explicitly defined. If it is 4 of 4 this actually creates more of an issue because 1 person could prevent withdrawal execution. It likely should be an M of N with a min threshold and a large enough set of key holders. More clarity is needed on how Maker representatives will make decisions on how/when to move the USDC between the Coinbase custody address and the PSM, what other actions they could undertake, how they might be replaced if there is an issue, and how to ensure the scope of their actions doesn’t unilaterally increase. Might it make sense to reduce the size of this deal? $1.6B or ~25% of the PSM is significant and brings with it more enhanced diligence. Maybe it makes more sense to start with a smaller amount? A $10M or $100M loss is a far cry from $1B+.    Given the complexity and risk associated with multi-sig controls (we are talking about $1.6B after all!) I can’t help but feel we’re pushing a rock up hill here. The lack of a formal company that MKR holders are actual shareholders in is just adding a lot more friction here in the name of “decentralization”. A lot of these concerns above would be non-issues if it was a formal company with an elected board, and those board members underwent DD and controlled the multi-sig. Through MIP81, we’re basically trying to replicate that, but in an inadequate way and without the legal support for MKR holders if issues arise.  An On-Chain Alternative What might be better and more aligned with the “DeFi” ethos is exactly what @JohnnyF suggested.     JohnnyF:  The part I do not understand: why does Coinbase have to have custody of the USDC for this at all? It seems to me they just do nothing with them. Why not custody it ourselves? We could designate a Maker-controlled USDC address, and all USDC held in that address receive some revenue share. They can easily and automatically check the balance each day and pay the revenue in a pre-defined interval, maybe weekly. This also solves the problem of ‘how does MKR get the funds back’ and in that specific case, everyone has to agree that it doesnt increase risk for Maker at all compared to the status quo. Even @ChrisBlec should be OK with that.   Have a vault contract that holds the USDC that is managed fully on-chain by MKR governance votes with the only actions to move from the vault address to the PSM address and vice versa. This way Coinbase can automatically send USDC rewards to it from their own whitelisted deposit address whenever they want, based on the vault address balance. This could potentially even occur on a per block basis, based on the deposit balance, less already paid rewards. If Maker decides it needs the USDC it can pull it upon a proper governance vote. If Coinbase wishes to cease the rewards program/agreement it can at any time. It can also update the rewards rate as it chooses to. So this would actually enable Coinbase to be more flexible and nimble, and reduce the amount of friction with regards to notice around changes to the agreement/program. While this structure isn’t completely under Coinbase’s custody and may not give them the showcase piece in the way they’re hoping for, I think it could present a novel more decentralized way of having funds “locked” in a mutually agreed upon custody arrangement that showcases the programmable and verifiable benefits of a distributed ledger. If @CB_Institutional is looking to support Maker and doesn’t intend to do anything with the USDC in custody (which it has repeated a few times now), and they are simply looking to keep USDC from being redeemed so that the fiat stays sticky in the banks and guarantees revenue for Circle and Coinbase (my reading between the lines), then this solution satisfies those goals. If the vault contract is simple and audited, I would argue that holistically it’s more secure than the currently proposed solution given all the other off-chain risks that have been highlighted in this MIP so far (regulatory, custody, bankruptcy, co-mingling, accounting, multi-sig and Maker representative risk and their potential doxing). Is this something that @CB_Institutional would be open to? To be more custodial for Coinbase, potentially the contract could be slightly more complex and be a 2/2 on-chain multi-sig with a time delay where Coinbase also has a key to authorize vault actions. In this implementation, if funds are deposited or withdrawn it would be a 2 stage process:  Maker governance vote approval triggers an on-chain approval signature in the vault contract to satisfy the first 1 of 2 signatures; The Coinbase key completes their 2 of 2 signature for approval of the deposit or withdrawal;  In the case of a withdrawal, if Coinbase does not sign within a certain number of blocks the withdrawal transaction would go through, ultimately leaving withdrawal control up to Maker governance and MKR holders. In the case of a deposit by Maker, if Coinbase doesn’t sign within a certain number of blocks the deposit would not go through, leaving the deposit amount (and any claim to future rewards by Maker) ultimately in Coinbase’s control. All without a corporate setup, extreme DD and lengthy legal contracts. I think this would still have PR value for both Maker and Coinbase, and wouldn’t increase any additional legal or regulatory risk for either party because Coinbase would be making rewards payments to a smart contract that is only governed by a decentralized group of MKR holders.       iammeeoh:  [Personal Note: I want to thank @prose11, all the organisers and Alesia for this. It was very useful and the format is good (also for future similar events).]   I second this! A lot was covered in that community call and added some much needed additional clarity. Thanks you! This whole process is very exciting and I’m actually still amazed at the quality of thought given how diverse the contributors are.

content.content: CC: @MIP-Editors

CB_Institutional:  We would like to formally submit MIP 81: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards for a vote in the October cycle. We appreciate the community’s engagement and comments and look forward to the vote which will occur from October 10 - 24.   This is unfortunate. Despite a lot of good details and potential, I think this moving to a vote is premature. This MIP is still lacking important specification around:  the entity onboarding; who the 4 Maker representatives are and how they are elected; and the governance and multi-sig structure for the representatives to move USDC in/out of the PSM, what else they can do, and how they may be replaced if there are issues;  Especially for $1.6B USDC! To put this in perspective, the details presented in the HVB and RFA MIP specifications are superior and far more detailed, and there is much less risk ($100MM DAI respectively). Additionally, I proposed a more decentralized approach that, in my view, reduces regulatory and legal risk for both parties, which further built on @dbkcan’s initial smart contract idea here. @monkey.irish hinted at this as well.     monkey.irish:  We believe there are solutions to the known issues that can be solved from a technology perspective. One example… As a technology partner exploring a generic technology solution with Coinbase Institutional Technology, we received some clarification as to what digital assets can be custodied with CB besides standard ERC20 tokens. We specifically asked whether CB institutional could custody a smart contract which could contain USDC tokens. Given an affirmative answer by CB Custody - we provided an outline of a smart contract that could be custodied by them. This is currently being reviewed by the Coinbase Custody technical team and we are expecting feedback soon. Depending on feedback from CB Custody technical team, this smart contract implementation approach could provide several benefits to both Maker and CB. Specifically:  Removing any concerns about incremental bankruptcy and regulatory risks Whilst an initial Real World entity will be needed to enter into an agreement with Coinbase Custody - human interaction for the ongoing management of our USDC position could be eliminated Direct integration with Maker - allowing Maker to remove USDC funds from Custody directly through the smart contract instantaneously  When we receive further feedback from Coinbase Technical team - we would plan to develop this proposed implementation if requested by this MIP. If not, CES will plan to perform the tasks as listed in this MIP.   While Coinbase has updated the MIP to say     CB_Institutional:  In the future, Coinbase and Maker will automate transactions between the PSM and Prime account via smart contract or API.   I believe this option should be explored before putting ~20% of Maker’s USDC PSM in the hands of 4 presently unknown individuals. If this MIP passes, the soonest the rewards will take effect is on October 15th (at the earliest) which would result in ~5,063,013.69 USDC rewards for the remainder of 2022 (at best). While that revenue is great, the ROI still feels out of balance given the lack of details. We’re risking $1.6B with 4 presently unknown people, with an unclear disaster recovery plan, for potentially ~$5M in revenue.  Note: FWIW I don’t think the risk is with Coinbase custody at this point, it’s to do with the lack of transparency around the Maker representatives and the mechanics.  Unfortunately, given this MIP is only paying out rewards until the end of 2022, I feel like the timing on this hasn’t aligned well and would have preferred to see this pushed to the November voting cycle with more of the remaining details ironed out. Sadly, I will be voting “no” for these reasons, and would urge others to do so as well. I hope that the remaining details can be refined and this MIP can be put forward for the November vote, potentially with an extension from Coinbase to pay rewards until the end of February 2023 so that the same 3 month trial period initially proposed is available.

content.content: This is the solution Maker deserves. @CB_Institutional please engage with CES in a constructive and timely manner to make this a reality.

We’re excited to support this proposal from Coinbase, which has a lot of positive implications for both parties and represents the beginning of a new partnership for MakerDAO. We hope its implementation can help to drive a path towards decentralization and resiliency for $DAI in the long-run. We do believe for the final proposal, however, that automating the USDC liquidity flows between the PSM smart contract and the Coinbase Prime account could be important from a technical perspective. These potential risks could be addressed if the funds were to be deposited into a Coinbase smart contract that didn’t have custodial access to the funds. The smart contract could automatically deposit funds back into the PSM based on programmatic thresholds. This way, Coinbase’s “custody” of the USDC would not become a hurdle to user redemptions in the event that a significant and unpredictable number of redemptions were to occur. As @monkey.irish has noted, the full technical solution is still in development; we appreciate the MakerDAO and Coinbase teams’ hard work and look forward to hearing more about the final structure at a high level once complete. A16z is an investor in Coinbase and MakerDAO. Full disclosures can be found here.

content.content: The idea is not to build this from scratch, but to leverage the MIP21 structure that already exists. The main difference is that instead of sending USDC to an arranger, USDC will be sent to this bespoke “safebox” contract, which is jointly operated by MakerDAO Governance and Coinbase. Governance would have the ability to remove funds from the “safebox” whenever it sees fit. As @hexonaut pointed out, this is a very simple smart contract. Effectively this would simply mean segregating part of the PSM and put it into this contract so it cannot be freely used until MakerDAO Governance decides otherwise. Apart from this MVP, we could still leverage some sort of IAM module to automatically pull funds from the “safebox” in case there’s too little liquidity in the PSM and take care of the rebalance automatically.

content.content: Rune is correct that any MIP should be interpreted as it has been ratified by MKR voters. MIPs are the most powerful governance tool that Maker Governance possesses. Because of this, they should be treated with great care. MKR voters voted to approve the MIP and that is now what should be carried out. Core Units and the Community should not reinterpret proposals after they have been ratified, without going through the appropriate process, otherwise the whole concept of MIPs and DAO Governance falls apart. The concerns being discussed over the past couple of days were flagged by GovAlpha and CES multiple times prior to the vote going live, including on multiple G&R calls and other discussion forums. To their credit Coinbase did subsequently make some amendments to the MIP to provide greater oversight from Maker Core Units and, consequently, protections for the DAO. From a Governance perspective, the MIP contains the following text within MIP81c2:     CB_Institutional:  A CES facilitator must, again through a public forum post, provide a verification of the technical appropriateness of the MIP81 designated solution. Should the verification not be forthcoming, this MIP will not move forward.   This is quite clear that CES have final say on any technical implementation being used here, and if they are not happy with such an arrangement, no further work will be done.

content.content: Whether MIPs or the past MIP6s, it’s not possible to document all the details when RWA collateral applications are posted. In the past year, we’ve learned a lot and where it make sense, we apply that learning forward. The deals we are doing today, and the speed at which we onboard, are a result of the learning and prior work from other RWA onboardings. Some of this is code based. When there are specific concerns by the community, it’s in Maker’s best interest to evaluate possible solutions that do not materially alter the ratified MIP. This is a balancing act of understanding when, and not, to apply friction. These decisions are not taken lightly. While there is risk with RWAs and they might have the appearance of all being the same, we manage that risk after the fact. These deals can be complicated and require a lot of manual intervention once onboarded. This is the part most people don’t see and it would be easy to assume it all works automatically. It gets more complicated when people intimately involved with these deals leave Maker so continuity is critical. I point this out since each onboarding has varying scope (and risk) of work when considering the lifetime of the deal. In order to help protector metadaos be successful, the details need to be managed after the onboarding so there isn’t a hot mess during vault adoption.

content.content: rune:  RWA is RWA and the risk is the effectively the same.   Brah, come on. This is just not true. The details of each deal, especially since none of them are the exact same, dramatically impact the risk profile. Stating otherwise is naive or disingenuous. The recent FTX blow up should give everyone here some pause to really reevaluate custody risk and remember what crypto is good for - the ability to not have to trust but to easily verify. I get not wanting to delay and start earning much needed protocol revenue but if if you wanted this done faster it could have taken the same line as the GUSD structure with Gemini that @SebVentures mentioned above. Frankly, in my view, that structure is much less risky all across the board. Less custody risk, legal risk, and chance of being deemed an investment contract (ie. a security). There is no legal precedent for a private entity making arbitrary payments to an immutable smart contract that is not under the control of a “common enterprise”. What constitutes a common enterprise within a DAO construct is an open question, but true decentralization (which Maker is closer to than Ooki DAO) likely plays a significant role. This includes governance! Putting $1.6B in custody with another party that is paying you a financial incentive (ie. expectation of profit), whether through shell corps or not, is either legally a demand deposit account or an investment contract. Since Coinbase Custody is not a deposit taking financial institution, this is likely to be deemed an investment contract. Now, using a BVI legal entity/trust as a front for legal capture may help address some of the BSA/AML requirements, this does not help protect against Coinbase engaging in an unregulated security offering. Maybe because of the legal structure this gives you a thinly veiled argument that the deal between the entity and Coinbase Custody is between 2 non-US entities (and ideally individuals) so it’s not their jurisdiction but given that all this out in the open, it’s pretty hard to argue that the entity doesn’t represent the DAO and MKR holders, some of which are US citizens. Furthermore, as a US publicly listed company, this activity will need to be in Coinbase’s SEC filings otherwise they will be making a material misrepresentation. So the SEC is gonna find out about it and your MiCA decentralization hacks aren’t relevant yet. MiCA won’t even come into effect until 2023/2024. Now, I may be sitting with a tinfoil hat on, and I’m sure Coinbase has very good lawyers, but based on my experience there is a non-zero chance that with the currently proposed custody structure, even with the ambiguity around DAOs, this could cause the USDC to be locked up as part of a legal proceeding. Seems like a big risk considering the implications when there are viable alternatives.     Patrick_J:  Rune is correct that any MIP should be interpreted as it has been ratified by MKR voters. MIPs are the most powerful governance tool that Maker Governance possesses. Because of this, they should be treated with great care. MKR voters voted to approve the MIP and that is now what should be carried out. Core Units and the Community should not reinterpret proposals after they have been ratified, without going through the appropriate process , otherwise the whole concept of MIPs and DAO Governance falls apart.   And while I 100% agree with @Patrick_J about the spirit of governance, let’s be real. A bunch of us brought up concerns about lack of final details on the custody arrangement and instead of extending the review period to taking time to address those issues, this MIP was rammed through to a vote. It was then passed easily by your delegated MKR stake. @rune you have more MKR than has typically been used on any vote in Maker’s governance history (it’s easy to see with chain analysis). So at the end of the day, it doesn’t really matter which way other people vote unless someone decides to come in and do a hostile takeover of Maker. I don’t want that. I don’t think most people that are involved in Maker want that. Nor does it make financial sense unless you wanted to be malicious, because MKR is dilutive and doesn’t accrue any value from stability fees or this yield right now. There’s no rational economic incentive to buy or hold MKR because it shouldn’t even have any value or reasonable expectation of profit. Its only purpose is to participate in setting the direction of a public good (idealistically). This is how I’ve viewed it personally. But let’s be intellectually honest here. @rune you want to move fast. So do lots of other people. We can both agree that process for the sake of process is stupid. But that’s not what’s happening here. Especially given there are better alternatives and we’re talking about 25-33% of the PSM, which if it gets caught up in any legal dispute or frozen as a result of counter party risk, will kill DAI’s peg. You can’t credibly use process when it suits you and hand wave it away when it doesn’t! This specific MIP13c3-SP12 process has been bastardized greatly. Not only in MIP81 but also MIP86 and MIP87. None of these are in the original spirit of MIP13c3-SP12 which is focused on low risk investments. I’ve added my commentary on each line item below with regards to MIP81.   Screen Shot 2022-11-10 at 11.16.40 PM1472×725 192 KB  While I support MIP86, and mostly support the direction of MIP81, let’s call a spade a spade here. My comments genuinely are meant to help move this forward and reduce risk for DAI and MKR holders because I want decentralized money to succeed and DAI is the best positioned at present. However, I’m also very concerned about the contagion if this blows up for any reason. DeFi has the potential to be much more resilient than relying on trusted intermediaries. Human’s can always be corrupted. Code can’t. It would behoove us to remember how many times, even in properly regulated structures, humans have messed up.  There is a scenario here where the USDC in Coinbase’s custody becomes an unsecured liability and frozen because this is deemed to be an investment contract or because BSA & AML requirements aren’t being adequately met if the ultimate beneficiaries of the yield are considered to be the DAO members and/or MKR voters. One could argue, as you have, that because Circle is the issuer, it doesn’t matter. But it absolutely does! While I agree there is still risk that Circle could freeze the assets, adding an extra counter-party in the middle and a whole other regulatory hook (securities violation?) increases the risk in a material way. It would be prudent to ensure there is credibility when claiming this isn’t the case. If Coinbase takes custody of the USDC and/or governance votes continue to be highly concentrated, then it will be much more difficult to avoid a regulatory hook. Especially in light of the recent LBRY token case ruling, which looks eerily similar to Ethereum’s early days and almost every other token project so far. It is not too late to address this by redistributing or burning your MKR tokens and letting people vote on an amendment to clarify what the technical appropriateness should be as described in the original MIP spec:     CB_Institutional:  A CES facilitator must, again through a public forum post, provide a verification of the technical appropriateness of the MIP81 designated solution. Should the verification not be forthcoming, this MIP will not move forward.   Specifically, to be that it should use a smart contract instead of a direct custody arrangement and ideally @monkey.irish or @dbkcan can add the spec around what that should/could look like so it is out in the open.  This will be my last post unless there are material changes at Maker. I will watch to see how MetaDAOs evolve because they do present some promise and the work that @Allan_Pedersen and a lot of the @strat-fin-core-unit (and ex RWA team) is doing really is groundbreaking. However, to me right now, MakerDAO is looking more like a really inefficient and risky private equity or mutual/hedge fund rather than the credibly neutral global money that I hoped it could be. If I can help in any way I’m easy to find. Wishing you well.

content.content: Robert, thanks for sharing your concerns today in the Discord. There has been significant organizational change since the Coinbase USDC rewards proposal was first introduced and approved. MIP81 while approved per Maker Governance - Ratification Poll for Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards (MIP81) - October 10, 2022 has not yet been funded or final terms agreed. I will attempt a summary including Forum links to help you and others get four corners around where things are relative to this proposal and its dependencies, plus context for further deep diving into the matrix. Corrections and clarity are welcomed by all who may know better the state of play! The latest technical status details on MIP81 are posted here. A smart-contract solution is being explored for holding the USDC in Coinbase Custody on-chain in a manner that gives MakerDAO governance some kind of physical control/participation with respect to transfers.    [RWA0XX] MIP81 Coinbase USDC Institutional Awards – Interim CES Domain Team Assessment Collateral Onboarding       Author(s): David Krett (@dbkcan) Contributors: @amusingxl MIP Reference: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip81-coinbase-usdc-institutional-rewards/17703  This assessment deviates from the standard smart contract technical assessment format because of the idiosyncratic nature of the RWA collateral type.   Risk Summary/Key Takeaways   This interim assessment assesses 2 alternative technical implementations for MIP81 - these are:   MIP65 Implementation - traditional custodial arrangement with a Real W…     HOWEVER, two days later we received an update from Collateral Engineering Services (CES), including that the team member who authored the assessment has been terminated and remaining contributors are moving forward as discussed here Interim Facilitator Assessment for CES-001 Meanwhile, an earlier post sets out how the proposal might proceed with a centralized legal entity operating as counterparty to Coinbase to facilitate the partnership. Please note additional conversation with respect to this proposal is happening here and should be consulted for a fuller picture of the ongoing discussion: MIP81 - Coinbase Institutional Rewards - Community Summary LARGER CONTEXT & DEPENDENCIES The approval of the Endgame MIP set in October Maker Governance - Ratification Poll for Endgame Prelaunch MIP Set - October 10, 2022 corresponded with Core Unit staff disruptions (with Collateral Engineering Services off-boarding having significant impact on business continuity MIP39c3-SP6: Core Unit Offboarding (CES-001)). The Endgame also implemented Core Unit mandate changes (Strategic Finance having a significantly greater scope MIP39c2-SP36: Modifying Strategic Finance Core Unit Mandate (SF-001)) leaving many implementation details and due diligence including legal review TBD with respect to this Coinbase MIP81. A request for additional funding to support the legacy Strategic Finance Core Unit for previously approved RWA business is pending and due for a governance vote next month:    MIP55c3-SP12: Commercial Risk and Legal Domain Work to Support SF-001 Expanded Mandate Related to RWAs RFC   MIP55c3-SP12: Commercial Risk and Legal Domain Work to Support SF-001 Expanded Mandate Related to RWAs  Preamble MIP55c3-SP#: 12 Author(s): @Aes  Contributors: Tags: spf Status: RFC Date Proposed: 2022-11-27 Date Ratified: TBD Amount Requested: 209K DAI Recipient Address: TBD Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip55c3-sp12-commercial-risk-and-legal-domain-work-to-support-sf-001-expanded-mandate-related-to-rwas/18943 Ratification Poll URL: TBD   Sentence Summary This SPF requests a 209K DAI…     At the same time, a funding request has been made for a future envisioned Endgame state structure to handle current RWA responsibilities, including this Coinbase MIP81.     MIP55c3-SP13 : Special Purpose Fund for developing Proof-of-Performance for Viridian Cluster RFC   MIP55c3-SP13 : Special Purpose Fund for developing Proof-of-Performance for Viridian Cluster  Preamble MIP55c3-SP#: 13 Author(s): @Hajive  Contributors: @Viridian   Tags: spf, viridian-cluster, Endgame Status: RFC Date Proposed: 2022-12-07 Date Ratified: Amount Requested: 500,000 DAI Recipient Address: TBC on SPF approval Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip-xx-special-purpose-fund-for-developing-proof-of-performance-for-viridian-cluster/19077   Sentence Summary This MIP will set up a Sp…     There remain many open questions about who should act and how on behalf of the DAO. Regarding Real World Assets (RWA) in general we have an outline from Rune as to how the work will be restructured within the organization:    [WIP] Scope Framework Example Draft: Scope 3 - The Real World Asset Collateral Scope Framework Governance   [WIP] Scope Framework Example Draft: Scope 3 - The Real World Asset Collateral Scope Framework  This is a formatting draft with placeholder content aimed to provide a scaffolding that can be used by the community to collaborate on the language that will aim to be ready for an MKR vote at the end of Q1 2023. In practice the Scope Frameworks will be implemented as 12 separate stand-alone MIPs.  The formatting draft does not represent the final result or the terms or parameters that will be releva…     For further context, note that the very active conversation about the Gemini/GUSD partnership led to this thread yesterday which refers back to the RWA Scoping process introduced above to begin next month: Quality of Maker’s Risk Management None of this answers the substance of your questions and concerns, but hopefully provides some roadmap to make the inside operations of things more legible. ~ Kianga

Which was then reiterated on September 8th:     CB_Institutional:  Should Governance choose to transfer assets off-platform it may instruct and settle these transfers almost instantaneously in USDC (<6 mins), consistent with Coinbase Prime’s standard offering. discourse_list.title: MIP81 - Coinbase Institutional Rewards - Community Summary

content.content: As the original MIP81 got a lot of interaction and contains some misleading information, this document aims to provide an updated place for more information and to help the community to highlight the most important points of the proposal that the community needs to take into consideration and what is the stage of the proposal. This is a best effort work and shouldn’t be relied on for investment decisions. Feel free to reach in case of errors or substantive omissions so I can correct.  High level overview MakerDAO will, through a MKR legal entity, use Coinbase Custody services to deposit an amount of USDC. This deposit will be held in the name of the MKR legal entity and left untouched. Coinbase will provide a reward on this deposit paid in USDC. The current reward rate proposed is 1.5% until the end of 2022. There is no time commitment from MakerDAO.  Pro:  Ability to generate 20M+ of annualized revenues in a scalable way while keeping a good liquidity Only proposal fitting this revenue generation/liquidity spot USDC in custody is not unwound, unwrapped or otherwise invested so the only additional risk that MakerDAO takes on is counterparty risk on the custody   Cons:  Expose a big chunk of MakerDAO assets to Coinbase Custody International Ltd counterparty risk Increase the regulatory risk as Coinbase could freeze the USDC in their custody on top of Circle freezing the USDC address. Notice CES is working on an idea to wrap USDC to fix those two previous issues. Similar result (more revenues but with more complexities and potentially slightly lower liquidity) might be achieved with MIP65 using money market funds   Next steps:  Figure out the MKR legal entity and who set it up (arranger?). Provide further clarity on the custody risk through a legal assessment of bankruptcy implications for digital asset custody in Ireland. Get more clarity on the liquidity profile (does it need governance interaction or is it a smart contract, do we want a hot or cold wallet, the latter being slower but more secured)   Legal structure The structure contemplated might be close to HVBank/MIP65. An orphaned entity (MKR legal entity) could be spun up to contract with Coinbase Custody International Ltd. Assuming it is a structure similar to the RWA Foundation, it will be managed by third party professional corporate servicers. MKR legal entity will recognize the MakerDAO loan with a Deed poll. MakerDAO will be able to send instructions to the directors through the issuance of DAO Resolutions in Executive Spells.  image922×397 10.8 KB  The custody of our USDC by Coinbase Custody International Ltd is probably the most significant risk in this construct. One part is technical. Is USDC safer under Coinbase custody than sitting under the PSM smart contract? The answer is probably that it is more risky (e.g. they can lose the keys, we can’t). This is mitigated by the fact that Coinbase is custodying 88 billions dollars of digital assets. They are on the top tier of digital asset custodians.  the theft, loss or destruction of private keys required to access any crypto assets held in custody for our own account or for our customers may be irreversible Coinbase 10Q  Another part is legal. Digital assets are new and therefore there is little history of what happens in a bankruptcy. The counterparty, Coinbase Custody International, is located in Ireland and is a dedicated entity. Legal work should be done to get more clarity, if possible, on this front.  Moreover, because custodially held crypto assets may be considered to be the property of a bankruptcy estate, in the event of a bankruptcy, the crypto assets we hold in custody on behalf of our customers could be subject to bankruptcy proceedings and such customers could be treated as our general unsecured creditors Coinbase 10Q  The last part is regulatory, as Coinbase will have to comply with regulators. It is unclear if that’s a significant risk change as USDC in the PSM can be frozen as well by Centre Consortium/Circle. Some counterparty risks are detailed in the MIP65 counterparty risk post.  Commercial terms In the MIP, Coinbase proposes a reward rate up to 1.5% of the USDC under custody. Currently, the risk-free rate in $ term (we will use SOFR here) is 2.25% and expected to move to 3% shortly. Coinbase will not use the USDC deposited in custody. Coinbase also doesn’t manage the underlying collateral of USDC as this is done by Circle. Nevertheless, under their Centre Consortium partnership, Circle has a revenue sharing agreement with Coinbase (see excerpt below from Circle S4). The ratio of revenue sharing is not specified but we can suppose it is between 50 and 100%. This agreement is probably limited to USDC that is at Coinbase (custody services or trading services) which explains the need to put the USDC in Coinbase’s custody.  As part of our and Coinbase’s investment in the development of the Centre Consortium, we entered into agreements with Coinbase, pursuant to which we share any revenue generated from USDC reserves pro rata based on (i) the amount of USDC distributed by each respective party and (ii) the amount of USDC held on each respective party’s platform (i.e. held in its customers’ accounts) in relation to the total amount of USDC in circulation (the “Revenue Share Arrangement”). The Revenue Share Arrangement requires the parties to calculate their revenue allocation a daily basis and provides for an annual true-up mechanism by which the revenue share is adjusted and paid per each party’s pro rata allocations. The Revenue Share Arrangement may only be terminated upon the mutual agreement of the parties.  The Coinbase reward is not directly linked to the $-risk free rate. But, as we have seen, it would be unwise from Coinbase to set the reward rate above what they get from Circle in their revenue sharing agreement. USDC is invested in short-term, safe instruments (mainly US gov debt instruments with an average 40-day maturity and cash deposits), so the risk-free rate is a good proxy. Furthermore, this rate expires at the end of 2022 so we can imagine that, should Coinbase want to continue generating a share of yield backing from Circle, it will update the rate for January 2023 to be competitive relative to alternatives that might be spun up in the meanwhile. Three alternatives to this MIP could be considered. First, fiat-backed stablecoin issuers could offer the same reward structure without having the need of putting the stablecoin in custody (keeping them in the PSM). This would be ideal as we would get a yield while keeping ample intra-block liquidity and taking zero additional risks. In a free competitive market, we should be able to earn close to the risk-free yield. One concern could be the very adverse regulation that those issuers have to face. The second solution would be moving those assets (USDC) off-chain and investing them in very short-term instruments (e.g. overnight repo). It is something a structure like MIP65 could achieve quite easily. The custodian “concern” would be reduced by using a traditional asset custodian like JPMorgan. Nevertheless, such a structure involves more counterparties (crypto-broker, bank, …) which is always a risk. It is also less transparent as being off-chain. Finally, the speed would most likely be slower. Finally, a product like Backed Finance or tokenized MIP65 could provide a good on-chain solution if the underlying is a money market fund. Nevertheless, this would require strong market adoption. Those solutions, while probably the endgame, are not there yet. TradFi risk-free yield should be a floor in DeFi as well due to arbitrage. In that sense, allocating capital in the Coinbase Institutional Rewards MIP81 doesn’t seem ideal. Yet it is the only option available and a game changer for MakerDAO. As depicted in the diagram below, MIP81 fit the algorithmic short-term allocation. Even with a 1.6B allocation, we would retain enough PSM layer intrablock liquidity to ensure the peg.  943×478 32.2 KB  Maker Community should also consider second order effects of this proposal. A Maker competitor could easily get a similar proposal and pass the reward to its customers (through a DSR-like mechanism). MakerDAO doesn’t have a concrete solution to compete by setting the DSR to 1.5% as well as it would be quite costly. Therefore, implementing this MIP would also be seen as a defensive action in a world where TradFi yield is coming to DeFi.

Rahii:  Can someone tell me what’s wrong with this comment and why is this flagged ?   Don’t take it personal. Some folks aren’t happy with this proposal, specially those that dislike CB. And no, it was not me that flagged it  I have never done such a thing, as much garbage that gets post it on this here forum, I take it with a grain of salt and give everyone the benefit of the doubt. You should do the same. Onwards and upwards!     SebVentures:  One part is technical. Is USDC safer under Coinbase custody than sitting under the PSM smart contract? The answer is probably that it is more risky.   I think this can be argued in both cases. Sanctions can be impose with provided guidelines to those who fail to follow prudent requirements. This is then follow by an investigation and sanction proceedings before sanctions are imposed. Some will argue that having a Trust Structure in place is a lot more difficult to sanction than a smart contract that’s controlled by a centralized entity (Circle as an example). All sanctioning steps take time. And last, this ecosystem has begged for guidelines and yet here we are. Here’s an interesting read on how the Russian sanctions failed to pinpoint Oligarchs assets: No, trusts are not impenetrable shields for oligarchs’ assets

SebVentures:  Cons:  Expose a big chunk of MakerDAO assets to Coinbase Custody International Ltd counterparty risk Increase the regulatory risk as Coinbase could freeze the USDC in their custody on top of Circle freezing the USDC address. Similar result (more revenues but with more complexities and potentially slightly lower liquidity) might be achieved with MIP65 using money market funds    @SebVentures I would just like to point out that as discussed here MIP81: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards - #201 by monkey.irish @CES has been in discussion with the @CB_Institutional  technical team about the possibility of @CB_Institutional holding in custody collateral indirectly through a simple custom smart contract (which we have provided a high level outline to CB and are still waiting for feedback). Should this be possible, under the proposed smart contract structure - all concerns about Counterparty/Bankruptcy risk are eliminated as Maker retains complete control over the collateral (even if Coinbase were to lose their private keys) simply by having a function within the smart contract which allows Maker to return the funds held in the contract to the PSM and which cannot be blocked by any party. Obviously, the USDC regulatory risk still exists regardless of where the USDC is held (in custody or within the PSM). Given the above I think that readers of this post should not reach any conclusions about the “Cons” as the actual technical implementation which still needs to be developed by @collateral-core-unit (subject to a positive vote) - may mitigate the cons you have identified, and furthermore move their rewards proposal into the 0-block liquidity in your ALM chart above.

dbkcan:  Should this be possible, under the proposed smart contract structure - all concerns about Counterparty/Bankruptcy risk are eliminated as Maker retains complete control over the collateral (even if Coinbase were to lose their private keys) simply by having a function within the smart contract which allows Maker to return the funds held in the contract to the PSM and which cannot be blocked by any party.   @dbkcan would you agree that in the above scenario, there is little difference in the Coinbase proposal vs the GUSD proposal, except that:  GUSD allow us to use our standard PSM Coinbase requires this additional step of sending the USDC in this ``external’’ contract, but still completely under the control of Maker?  It looks like (2) is just a legal need from Coinbase to work within their legal agreements:     SebVentures:  Coinbase will not use the USDC deposited in custody. Coinbase also doesn’t manage the underlying collateral of USDC as this is done by Circle. Nevertheless, under their Centre Consortium partnership, Circle has a revenue sharing agreement with Coinbase (see excerpt below from Circle S4).

Yes I would agree with your conclusion. However, there would be some additional technical work required for the integration (which I don’t think will be overly complex) and obviously the incremental returns being offered which should more than offset the integration work.

I do agree that it is a smart solution. Nevertheless, at this stage I understand it is an idea. It will put a note nevertheless. Please, keep me informed if this translate to a decision so I can update.

Thank you @ACREinvest - we will be posting a long-form response shortly to assuage any concerns. In short: rest assured, while the industry faces liquidity struggles, client assets are safe at Coinbase, held 1:1, unless explicitly directed by the customer, as you can review in our public, audited financial statements. We remain in a strong capital position. We have immaterial exposure to FTX (CB Ventures made a small equity investment), and none to Genesis Trading. Stay tuned, and thanks for engaging!
Do you plan on doing real time proof of reserves?

Thanks for the update. Can you please provide a bankruptcy analysis for Maker’s assets, if Coinbase entered bankruptcy? what would Maker’s position be in the bankruptcy and what is required for Maker to recover its collateral?  Approval of the bankruptcy court, for example?

Hi Maker Community, Given the market backdrop, I’d like to provide some color and reassurance on assets held at Coinbase. We recently published a blog post regarding our approach to transparency, risk management, and consumer protection. In addition to the blog’s overview about our broader business, I want to reinforce the security of Coinbase Prime/Custody specifically. This means:  There can’t be a run on the bank. Client assets are held 1:1 - unless explicitly directed by the customer Assets are 100% segregated in on-chain wallets (no commingling with other client funds or Coinbase’s business) Funds are held in hot wallets or 100% cold storage per the client’s sole discretion via our state-of-the-art security protocols Comprehensive insurance coverage Our processes, books, and records are fully audited via SOC1/SOC2 reports  While many in the industry have been exposed to fraud and liquidity struggles, Coinbase remains unimpacted:  No exposure to Alameda Immaterial exposure to FTX/FTT ($15 million in deposits) No exposure to Genesis / zero exposure to Genesis Trading No exposure to Gemini We only hold $168mm of our $5.6B USD resources at third party venues. Reference our limited exposure to third parties on pg. 10 of our shareholder letter.   Coinbase has been focused on servicing clients in need and supporting others in the industry through this time - we’ll continue to do everything we can to protect our customers while safely growing the cryptoeconomy. Broadly speaking, in the highly unlikely event of a Coinbase bankruptcy, our client agreements are explicit that Coinbase does not have a property interest in the digital assets we hold for customers. Specifically, we believe that the USDC on Coinbase’s platform on behalf of Maker would not be subject to the claims of our creditors. Finally - regarding the status of MIP81: we are still in the execution phase, and do not yet have custody of Maker’s funds. We are looking forward to finalizing implementation, onboarding, and providing a steady stream of revenue to Maker through our partnership. As stated in the MIP, our rewards program is not contingent on external parties or market conditions; we pay USDC Rewards from our own well-funded inventory of USDC. Current market conditions have in no way diminished our enthusiasm for – or ability to deliver on – MIP81. Please reference the following resources:  Our approach to Risk Management, Transparency, and Consumer Protection Tweet regarding Genesis Your fund are Safe at Coinbase-and always will be Our Approach to Crypto Financing

You are not answering my specific bankruptcy analysis question. Simple question:  would Maker likely be subject to the bankruptcy court’s authority in recovering its collateral in a bankruptcy? We need a serious reply from an attorney with bankruptcy expertise…  can you please provide this??

CB_Institutional:  Client assets are held 1:1 - unless explicitly directed by the customer   Can you describe a scenario where a client has directed you not to hold assets 1:1? What does that mean exactly? The ratio in context refers to assets we would deposit vs the potential for Coinbase to rehypothecate or use those assets. How is a custodial account ever not holding 1:1 if the client gives you some kind of “direction”? Are you referring to a situation where the client withdraws funds from custody? In that case the assets are still held 1:1 vis-a-vis the amounts deposited by customer and amounts held in a segregated wallet. Please explain. Of course top of mind is the situation at Grayscale and noting that the letter you provided (attached in the tweet shared below) reports balances as of September 30, 2022. What is the reason you could not or did not provide confirmation of assets in custody as of today’s date? Wallet addresses and on-chain proof have not been provided for Grayscale’s products citing security concerns. Under MIP81, would the MakerDAO community (and thus the general public) have access to the on-chain addresses where our USDC is being stored?   twitter.com    Grayscale @Grayscale  4) All digital assets that underlie Grayscale’s digital asset products are stored under the custody of Coinbase Custody Trust Company, LLC. Read more from @Coinbase’s CFO Alesia Haas, and CEO of Coinbase Custody Aaron Schnarch: https://t.co/InBP9zPDkC      10:47 PM - 18 Nov 2022           82                14

CB_Institutional:  we pay USDC Rewards from our own well-funded inventory of USDC.   Can you elaborate on the source of funding for your inventory of USDC? It’s often said in the context of Web2 that if services are free, the customer is the product. Here, not only are custodial services free for MakerDAO, but we are paid for being a customer. Accordingly, ACREinvest would gain comfort through more specific disclosures to better understand how Coinbase sustainably pays for this program, especially since there is no guarantee of or commitment to offer any particular rate after December 2022. We have seen reports that Circle reduced yields to zero on one of its retail yield offerings seemingly as a result of Genesis Trading halting redemptions and ceasing lending operations this week. By “exposure” mentioned below are you referring strictly to equity investments made to any of the FTX entities in bankruptcy and Genesis?     CB_Institutional:  We have immaterial exposure to FTX (CB Ventures made a small equity investment), and none to Genesis Trading.     Are you impacted as a customer in any way that could reduce the inventory available for funding this rewards program in the future?   Is there a Coinbase entity that is an institutional customer of Circle International Bermuda Limited (“Circle Bermuda”) for the purposes of generating yield for this MakerDAO rewards program?   Does Coinbase lend its own Bitcoin to Circle Bermuda any other party to generate yield?   Does Coinbase pledge bitcoin to Silvergate or other lenders and borrow USD for the purchase of USDC?   You have previously referred to having a revenue sharing agreement with Circle.    MIP81: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards   The USDC that Coinbase uses to pay USDC Institutional Rewards comes from Coinbase’s inventory of USDC. Coinbase funds the inventory from its own purchases of USDC from Circle, from purchases of USDC from users of the Coinbase platform, and from payments that Coinbase receives pursuant to its revenue sharing agreement with Circle, the issuer of USDC.   Can you provide more details on that agreement or provide a link to any of your public filings that describe this relationship? You state that “purchases of USDC from users of the Coinbase platform” are in your pool of inventory. How so? Which users are you referring to? In what way and under what circumstances is Coinbase a buyer of USDC from these users? Is Coinbase permitted to rehypothecate or borrow USDC from balances held by some Coinbase customers to pay rewards to MakerDAO? Thank you

The lack of answer every time bankruptcy risk comes up with respect to RWA is your answer. Either:  We don’t know; or It would likely not be favourable to MKR and DAI holders  There is no precedent for this stuff afaik and it’s not in the best interest of the party that is in control of MakerDAO assets to acknowledge this for fear of being wrong (and legally liable) or to ruin a deal. Furthermore, any bankruptcy lawyer worth their fee would tell you the same. Bankruptcy is always a crap shoot, even in “simple” cases. This is not one of those.
